title: Thune RESPONDS to Dem threats on DHS funding after ICE shooting
description:
Senate Majority Leader John Thune, R-S.D., joins ‘Fox News Live’ to respond to Democrats seeking to block DHS funding after the Minneapolis ICE shooting, how JD Vance is taking action to curb fraud and more. #foxnews #news #ice #dhs #immigration #johnthune #congress #minneapolis #reneegood #jdvance #breakingnews #politics #lawenforcement #bordersecurity #fundingdebate #governmentshutdown #uspolitics

transcript:
All
right, let's get out to Senate Majority
Leader John Thun who is joining us from
the great state of Texas down at the
southern border right now where the
border is now secure. A huge
accomplishment for the Trump
administration really day one. A
majority leader, thank you for joining
us on our debut show.
>> Great to be with you. Thanks Aisha. I
want to get to those border numbers in
just a second, but first let's talk
about the immigration battle that is
escalating across the country and how
it's going to bleed into what's
happening uh on Capitol Hill. We've got
Democrats now that are so angry over
this ICE shooting in Minneapolis that
they want to block funding. In fact, the
senator from Connecticut, Chris Murphy,
tweeted this. Democrats cannot vote for
a Homeland Security budget that doesn't
restrain the growing lawlessness of this
agency. So, Majority Leader, how are you
going to respond to these growing
threats from these Democrats?
>> Well, it's kind of expected, Aisha. The
Democrats are uh right now uh pretty
much unhappy about anything and Trump
derangement syndrome is the big cause of
that. So, there isn't anything that this
president can do even on matters as
basic as enforcing the law. Obviously,
the ICE agents are enforcing uh
immigration laws in this country and um
you know, they're running into
resistance from some of these uh uh blue
states, cities, and and um you know,
states around the country that are
resistive to enforcing enforcement of
those laws. But at the end of the day,
it's their job, and it's what we asked
them to do. uh it's part of the
enforcement that this president ran on
and was elected on and that is to make
sure that people who are in this country
are here in this country legally. And so
um that's that's just the way it is. And
uh you know we've got to back our law
enforcement officers. Uh the Democrats
may resist doing that that they've been
very clear about that for some time now.
Um they don't want to see the laws in
this country enforced. That's why they
had a open border for the past uh four
years down here under Biden. But uh this
is an administration uh with a backing
of the Congress that is going to stand
behind our law enforcement officers.
>> One more quick question on Minnesota.
The vice president earlier in the week
uh mentioned your names that he talked
to you about nominating and hopefully
swiftly confirming a new assistant
attorney general that would look into
fraud not only in Minnesota but across
the country. Have you been talking to
the White House about names and
potentially when that might happen? Uh
we have had conversations with the with
the white house Aisha. That's right. And
uh I think in and absolutely we should
be investigating fraud in this country.
If you have states uh in this case the
state of Minnesota but there other
states particularly blue states around
the country who have been looking for
ways to abuse and game the system uh not
follow the law when it comes to uh
benefits that are going to people in
this country in some cases illegal
people in some cases people who are not
qualified to receive those benefits.
That's fraud and that's a ripoff of the
American taxpayer and that needs to be
investigated. And so if the White House
wants to pursue that, yeah, we are more
than happy to work with them to ensure
that the laws in this country are being
followed and the people who are supposed
to get benefits and get assistance from
the federal government are getting it,
but those that who are not uh are not
gaming the system and committing fraud.
>> Okay, let's talk about the border. It
was a winning issue for Republicans in
2024. And if you pull up the numbers, I
mean, they're fascinating to look at. We
had over 10,000 on any given day
encounters at the border, apprehensions
at the border every single day uh during
the Biden administration. Today, it's
somewhere close to maybe just about 200
people coming across the border. So, the
numbers are incredible. But take a look
at what's developed now. Recent Fox News
polling shows Americans seem to have
moved on from the border story. Across
the board, immigration is at the bottom
of what they want. President Trump to be
paying attention to. In fact, just about
3% of Democrats, 12% of Republicans, and
6% of independents want him to
prioritize immigration. So, majority
leader, how do you make the border,
which is a success, and immigration,
which is what everyone is now debating
about, how do you make those a winning
issue for Republicans in 2026?
Well, Aisha, I think every every
president uh would love to have their
policies be so effective that the
problem no longer exists. And
[clears throat] that's certainly uh you
could argue at least with President
Trump and his policies, there hasn't
been a single person and since he took
office, and it's almost a year now that
he's been in office, um who's been
released illegally into the country. Uh
this border is for all intents and
purposes secure. I was down here in
2021. I was here in 2023 uh both times
under the Biden administration and their
open borders policy and it was just it
was chaos. It was anarchy and you saw
that in the country. Drugs coming into
the country, weapons coming into the
country, human trafficking, all this
cartel activity, it's been shut down and
and that's a that's a huge win for the
American people and the president needs
to take credit for that. Um but we need
to continue to do diligence to ensure
that it doesn't become a problem again.
And I think that's where uh enforcing
the laws in this country, we are first
and foremost a nation of laws. Uh people
have to understand that this president
was elected on that. And uh so we're
going to continue to enforce the laws,
but pivot at the same time to these
other issues. And I think frankly um the
president has a great record to run out
of accomplishment when it comes to the
economy. Inflation is coming down, gas
prices are coming down, uh job growth
and job uh wage growth, I should say, is
up in this country. And I think as our
policies working with this
administration, with the president on
his economic policy agenda, continue to
be played out and implemented this next
year, you're only going to see that
improve and continue to improve for the
American people. They're going to have
more money in their pockets. They're
going to have safer streets because of
the the border policies, and they're
going to have new opportunities to get
ahead because of many of the things that
were included in the one big beautiful
bill.
>> Okay. Finally, uh you are backing
Senator John Cornin for uh the Texas
Senate seat for reelection. He's facing
a pretty crowded primary here. Um, do
you think that if Ken Paxton wins this
nomination that he would not be able to
win the general?
>> Well, I just I'm I'm here to support
Senator Cornin. He is an incredibly
effective senator for the state of
Texas. We also know, the polling shows
this, that if he is the nominee, that
the Texas Senate race is a much easier
path uh for us to continue to to hold
that seat and and and and spend a lot
less money in the state of Texas. And
so, obviously, we're interested in the
whole map. Uh we're looking at races
around the country. We want to deploy
resources and a um you know, wisely and
well and make sure that we're getting um
you know, the money into the places
where we can potentially pick up some
seats. and we would rather not spend a
lot of money in the state of Texas. And
I think John Cornin is our nominee
coming out of this primary uh enables us
to ensure that Texas remains Republican
uh in a way that doesn't cost a lot of
money and enables us to deploy resources
elsewhere where we have chances to pick
up seats.
>> Would a Donald J. Trump endorsement of
John Cornin in the next 60 days decide
this primary?
>> Totally. Absolutely. 100%. And um that
that would be wonderful if that happens.
So, have you have you asked? We're just
Senator Cornin is running hard. Um we're
doing everything we can to support him.
>> Uh yes, I have. Um yes.
>> Okay. Are we going to get one?
>> Well, I don't know about that. The
president makes his decisions on his own
time. Um we've had a number of
conversations about Texas Senate and uh
hopefully um you know in due time that
would be a great outcome and I think it
would obviously enable us to be uh
competitive a lot of places around the
country and and use resources wisely and
well. All right. Uh, we'll watch to see
what the president decides to do.
There's still a little bit of time for
him to think about this. Um, a majority
leader, thank you so much for joining
us. I know you're very busy, so we
appreciate the time. Good to see you.
Hey everyone, I'm Emily Compano. Catch
me and my co-hosts Harris Falner and
Kaylee Mcini on Outnumbered every
weekday at 12 PM Eastern or set your
DVR. Also, don't forget to subscribe to
the Fox News YouTube page for daily
highlights.

title: Homan RIPS Dems over anti-ICE rhetoric after Minneapolis shooting: ‘COMPLICIT!’
description:
Border czar Tom Homan reveals his assessment of the deadly Minneapolis ICE shooting, discusses the Trump administration’s immigration policy and more on ‘Fox News Sunday.’ #fox #media #breakingnews #us #usa #new #news #breaking #foxnews #foxnewssunday #politics #political #politicalnews #government #immigration #ice #iceshooting #minneapolis #reneegood #tomhoman #borderczar #controversy #lawenforcement #dems #rhetoric

transcript:
Joining us now is White House border Tom
Hman. Tom, thank you for being here.
Appreciate it. Immediately after the
shooting, you said that it would be
unprofessional to comment on what I
think happened in that situation. Let
the investigation play out and hold
people accountable based on that
investigation. Since that time, we've
seen a lot more evidence come out,
including cell phone video from the
officer who shot Renee Good. What is
your assessment now? Look, you know what
I've when I did that interview, I went
straight from an airplane tarmac to that
interview. So when someone shows me one
video, cherrypicked video and ask me to
comment, I just think it was
inappropriate for me to do so. But look,
I since then, I've looked at a bunch of
videos. Uh, and I believe I truly
believe that that officer thought his
life was in danger to take that action.
Now, look, we won't let the
investigation play out. You know,
there's a lot of things we all don't
know. There's probably a lot of video we
haven't seen, but the FBI has even ring
video there. What's the statement from
the officer? What's the statement from
the witnesses? What's ballistics? The
ballistics, you know, I'm sure they're
looking at ballistics in the forensics.
There's a lot of information needs to
come out. So, I I'm still going to say,
let's stop the hypo ready. You can't
compare this to murder. Murder requires
malice. That is just dangerous to put
that type of language out. Let the
investigation play out and see what and
see where see where it lies.
The DHS secretary, Christine Gnome,
concluded pretty quickly that this was a
domestic terrorism incident. She said
that while the scene was still being
processed and said the dead woman was
part of a left-wing disruption scheme,
you know, with those statements, why
should federal authorities be the ones
investigating it? It almost sounds like
there's nothing left to investigate.
>> Look, it's a federal crime to impede an
interfer with an ICE officer. And I
think look, it's a coordinated attack.
We can see what's happening throughout
the country. I think it's a funded
organized attack against ICE officers.
And what really irritates me is we we
the left wants to play this game that
ICE as you know they're not law
enforcement officers. They are federal
law enforcement officers. Impeding them
and interfering them is a is a crime. No
one would be arguing if you know if we
arresting people that interfere with DEA
before you know arresting a drug dealer
or US Marshall in attempts to arrest a
fugitive. If someone stood in your way,
that's a crime you would be arrested.
But it seems like they want to, you
know, they normalize, the media is
normalizing interference with ICE. It is
a crime to impede ICE officers. Bill
Malusian just put out a list of 18 of
the most worst of the worst in
Minneapolis. Many of them child sex
crimes, child rape, child sodomy. These
are the people we're looking for. For
anybody that's interfering, that is
unconscionable. We need to enforce law
and arrest these bad guys. We've already
arrested over a thousand people in that
state. and we're going to continue to do
exactly what Congress has allowed us to
do and what the law allows us to do.
>> Back to the investigation, you know, the
state authorities reject the
administration's claim that they don't
have any jurisdiction to investigate.
Um, and some Republican senators,
including Tom Tillis, Lisa Marowski,
took issue with them being excluded from
this probe, uh, saying that could create
unnecessary suspicion. And the Henipin
County Sheriff's Office said, "We've
spoken with sheriffs throughout our
county. We all agree that an
investigative process that excludes
local agencies has the potential to have
harmful implications nationwide. Why
should people trust that this
investigation will be fair?
>> It's a federal crime that needs to be
investigated by the FBI. That's the way
this whole system set up. I trust the
FBI to do the right thing.
>> We've also heard this justification that
um local authorities don't collaborate
with uh federal officials on law
enforcement. So, why should they be
involved now that it's time to
investigate a federal officer? Um, but
is this lack of collaboration a one-time
decision that's specific to this case,
or are we watching a new broader policy
roll out here?
>> No, look, that state's a sanctuary
state. It's a sanctuary city. They don't
work with us. And that's one of the
problems here and it's one of the reason
we're in the position we're in in that
city because law enforcement response
has been sporadic at best. This is
sanctuary city. Let's remember why we
why are we in that city right now?
Because you're a sanctuary city that
purposely releases public safety threats
back into the public. I just mentioned
about all these cases that child sex
crime, child sodomy, child rape that
they released back into the community.
These are people we have to go look for.
And who set the stage for all this? The
last four years on the open border,
millions of people released in this
country without vetting. A lot of
criminals, a lot of national security
threats. That's that's why we're there.
Let's not forget who set the stage on
this. So all these people on the
Democratic side and all these liberal
people want to scream and yell about our
law enforcement activities. They didn't
say a word when there's an open border.
They didn't say a word when half million
children were smuggling this country.
Lost track of 300,000 and they weren't
even looking for them. President Trump
in this administration found 129,000 of
them. They were silent then. They were
complicit on on on millions of people
being released in this country, many of
them criminals. didn't say a word. Now
all of a sudden, because we're trying to
fix four years of an open border, now
they're all of a sudden they got an
opinion.
>> There are already 2,000 or so federal
agents um in Minneapolis for this
massive crackdown that's tied in part to
this ongoing probe of alleged Somali
fraud. Um Fox is told that about a
thousand more Border Patrol agents are
going to be heading there to assist,
basically free up HSI officers. Um,
there's also this growing network of
local residents who are tracking ice
movements and warning people about them
and schools in the area are being given
the option of remote learning for the
next month because of how hot the
environment is getting. Yeah. Are you
concerned about what we're heading
toward? And what do you say to those
officials like Mayor Frey who's accused
the administration of just looking for
an excuse to invoke the insurrection
act?
>> It's ridiculous. Bottom line is they
don't have to shut the schools down.
They can't give me one example where
ISIS walked into an elementary school or
a church or hospital. It's ridiculous.
And all this false narrative that
they're pushing is just going to double
down on hate against ICE. For instance,
calling in a murder that the mayor
calling it murder. The hateful rhetoric
has caused a lot of this violence. I
said way back in March, if the hateful
rhetoric doesn't decrease, there will be
bloodshed. Unfortunately, I was right.
And it's not over. There will be more
bloodshed unless we decrease the hateful
reddic to compare this officer to a
murder. Are you kidding me? Threats
against ICE officer uh actual attacks
are up 1300%. A lot of this based on the
hateful reic from people who don't
understand what's going on and don't
want to face the facts. If if you want a
safe city, if you want ICE out of your
city, then stop being a sanctuary city.
Give Icy access to your jail to arrest a
bad guy in the safety and security of a
jail which is safer for the officer,
safer for the alien, and safer the
community. You force us in the community
to find these people.
So sanctuary cities are sanctuaries for
criminals. More agents in your jail
means less agents in your community. But
don't don't mistake anything. We're
going to get this job done. If he forces
in the community to rest the bad guys,
that's exactly what we're going to do.
And when we do that, we may find others
who weren't a public safety threat,
weren't the target of the arrest, but
they're coming, too, because we'll
enforce immigration law. Work with us.
I'm begging you, stop the hate for
rhetoric. I don't want to see anybody
die. There's been too much death. Work
with us. Help us make your city safer.
>> Tom Hman, thank you so much for being
here. Really appreciate it.
>> Thank you. I'm Steve Ducey. I'm Brian
Kilme.
>> And I'm Anley Airheart. Click here to

We are seeing horrifying videos of ICE
agents battering down people's doors
without a warrant, racially profiling
people on the street.
>> This is not about safety. This is not
about immigration. This is about sewing
chaos on the streets of Minneapolis.
This is about political retribution.
>> This looks like modern-day slave
patrols.
Top Democrats holding a field hearing in
Minnesota to investigate ICE, slamming
the agency as protesters clash with
agents in Minneapolis. Here to react is
former Speaker of the House and Fox News
political analyst N. Genrich. Nude, it's
always great to have you on. Good
morning. Um, so obviously
>> Thank you. Obviously the Democrats think
this is a winning political issue going
into the midterms. I also remember knew
when they thought that BLM and you know
defund the police was what are your
thoughts? Is this going to be useful to
them politically speaking?
>> Well, you know, if you want to run as
the party that's pro illegal immigration
that is against deporting illegal
immigrants who are criminals uh that
wants to basically break the law against
federal officials. Remember, ICE is in
fact a federal agency and under federal
law, they have the right, they have the
duty to enforce the law and most
Americans agree uh that if you find
people who are here illegally uh that
you have the right to deport them. I
don't think there's any doubt about that
for most Americans. But the Democrats
have adopted across the board a pro-
illegal immigration uh you know pro-
allowing uh criminals rather than the
police and a willingness to encourage
people to break the law. I I don't think
that's sustainable.
>> Yeah, it's not sustainable. But again, I
get to the question of why. How much do
you think perhaps this has to do with
the census? The census counts everybody
whether they're illegal or not. And then
the uh the congressmen um are aortioned
according to population, not not
citizens. Do you think this could be
part of a way for them to hold on to
power? If if a lot of illegals get
deported and and and illegals continue
to not come to this country, uh they
lose power, don't they?
>> Well, I think it's deeper than that. I
think you're right. But in addition to
that, I think there's something at in
the core values of the left that is
always in favor of the criminal that was
true for domestic criminals, not just
for illegal immigrants. It's always
against the police. It's always against
authority. Uh and they just can't help
themselves. They have a visceral
immediate response that if you represent
authority, you must be bad. And if
you're a criminal, it was probably
something in your childhood. you know,
it's not your fault that you're a rapist
or a murderer and we shouldn't be too
difficult in dealing with you. I mean, I
personally think it's nuts, but for a
very substantial maybe 20% of the
country, uh, they really do believe
these kind of strange values.
>> Yeah, I couldn't agree more. Well, the
White House National Economic Council
Director Kevin Hasset says that Trump is
going to announce a major housing plan
at Davos and he's revealing that he will
let Americans tap their 401ks for down
payments. Watch this.
>> The truth is that fewer people are
buying homes right now than we've seen
pretty much in my lifetime. And the
reason is that we had runaway Biden
inflation and the down payment they
needed to buy a home went from about
$15,000 uh to about $32,000. And so
there's a real lot of room to make up
and we've got a whole bunch of policies
that are going to help people do that.
We're going to allow people uh to take
money out of their 401ks and use that
for down payment.
>> So new last week they said the president
said that he was going to stop private
equity firms from purchasing homes. So
homes are for people, not private equity
firms. And now this um and he's
announcing it at Davos where they said
you can you you won't own anything and
you'll be happy. So tell me about that.
>> Well well f first of all K as you know
is the ambassador to Switzerland. So
we're looking forward to seeing the
president next week at the World
Economic Forum. Um I I think he's making
a very calculated uh distinction.
Investing in a home, building up home
ownership is in fact a major step for
most Americans in preparing for
retirement. So why shouldn't you be able
to get the same tax break that you would
get in a 401k which helps you with your
retirement? And I think there's a real
desire here to reestablish home
ownership as a base for the American
system. And it was frankly compounded by
the way we allowed the politicians
allowed uh student loans to get out of
control. So all too many young people
graduated from college or from medical
school or law school owing so much money
that they couldn't afford to buy a home.
Well, we want to reverse that. We want
to make it easy to save up and to become
a homeowner because people behave
differently if they have an investment
in their neighborhood, if they have a
sense of property, if they're involved
in taking care of something, which in 20
or 30 years becomes a very valuable nest
egg. I mean, the number of senior
Americans whose biggest single asset is
their home is remarkable. And that was a
long-term project that moved us from
being a nation of renters to a nation of
property owners. And I think Prince I
think that President Trump is trying to
do the same thing.
>> Yeah. So once one side is uh defending
criminals um and against the other
side's trying to bring you a home. We'll
see how these midterms go, right? Uh new
King,
>> we appreciate you joining us so early in

title: CNN 2016 ICE ride-along resurfaces as Minneapolis tensions ERUPT
description:
‘Outnumbered’ discusses a resurfaced 2016 CNN ICE ride-along in Chicago as the immigration enforcement debate intensifies amid rising tensions and public safety concerns.

#fox #media #breakingnews #us #usa #new #news #breaking #foxnews #outnumbered #cnn #chicago #illinois #ice #immigration #deportation #border #enforcement #lawenforcement #police #crime #crimenews #crimestory #criminal #police #publicsafety #tensions #debate #ridealongs 

Don’t just watch Fox News—be part of it. Become a Fox News Patriot today. https://youtube.com/foxnews/join

Subscribe to Fox News: https://bit.ly/2vBUvAS
Watch more Fox News Video: http://video.foxnews.com
Watch Fox News Channel Live: http://www.foxnewsgo.com/

Download the Fox News app: https://foxnews.onelink.me/xLDS/cd5yhg3o

FOX News Channel (FNC) is a 24-hour all-encompassing news service delivering breaking news as well as political and business news. The number one network in cable, FNC has been the most-watched television news channel for 18 consecutive years. According to a 2020 Brand Keys Consumer Loyalty Engagement Index report, FOX News is the top brand in the country for morning and evening news coverage. A 2019 Suffolk University poll named FOX News as the most trusted source for television news or commentary, while a 2019 Brand Keys Emotion Engagement Analysis survey found that FOX News was the most trusted cable news brand. A 2017 Gallup/Knight Foundation survey also found that among Americans who could name an objective news source, FOX News was the top-cited outlet. Owned by FOX Corporation, FNC is available in nearly 90 million homes and dominates the cable news landscape, routinely notching the top ten programs in the genre.

description:
Fox News senior correspondent Steve Harrigan shares new video of the anti-I.C.E. protest in a Minnesota church and reports on the state's response on 'The Story.' #fox #media #breakingnews #us #usa #new #news #breaking #foxnews #thestorywithmarthamaccallum #ice #immigration #protest #church #religion #minnesota #politics #political #politicalnews #government #speech #law #border #harrigan #steveharrigan

FOX News Channel (FNC) is a 24-hour all-encompassing news service delivering breaking news as well as political and business news. The number one network in cable, FNC has been the most-watched television news channel for 18 consecutive years. According to a 2020 Brand Keys Consumer Loyalty Engagement Index report, FOX News is the top brand in the country for morning and evening news coverage. A 2019 Suffolk University poll named FOX News as the most trusted source for television news or commentary, while a 2019 Brand Keys Emotion Engagement Analysis survey found that FOX News was the most trusted cable news brand. A 2017 Gallup/Knight Foundation survey also found that among Americans who could name an objective news source, FOX News was the top-cited outlet. Owned by FOX Corporation, FNC is available in nearly 90 million homes and dominates the cable news landscape, routinely notching the top ten programs in the genre.

transcript:
Let's dig into all of it with Border
Patrol Chief Greg Bavino. Greg, good to
have you on the program. I want to play
this soundbite from President Trump
yesterday as he departed the White House
because he told me uh that he is not
ready to pull the trigger on the
Insurrection Act. Here he is.
>> Mr. President, what's your trigger for
the Insurrection Act? What's the trigger
for the Insurrection Act in Minnesota?
What are you waiting for? Well, the
Insurrection Act and which has been used
by 48% of the presidents, and if I
needed it, I'd use it. I don't think
there's any reason right now to use it,
but if I needed it, I'd use it. It's uh
very powerful.
>> Do you agree with that assessment, Greg?
Right now, it's not necessary to send in
troops.
>> Aisha, thanks for having me, and it's
good to see you. The president is spot
on with his comments on the Insurrection
Act. Uh the president remains very
focused on what's happening here in
Minneapolis. He relies on uh on the
ground leaders such as me, intelligence
reports, and other information to make
that decision. But he's spot on when he
says right now it's not needed. Uh we've
got the situation under control. Uh
several thousand law enforcement agents
here and we're conducting that Title 8
immigration mission unabated.
>> Oh, you are picking up a lot of
different people that are impeding on
these investigations. Some of them are
breaking into federal vehicles. This one
right here, uh, posted online by the
Department of Homeland Security. His
name is Raul Gutierrez, and he's accused
of destroying FBI vehicles. If we'll put
it up on the screen here. There he is.
Um, and Alexis McAdams, who's been on
the ground reporting for us. She was
telling me that these groups are so
organized, Greg. They're using signal to
track where ICE officers are going.
They're doxing these ICE officers. Do we
know who is organizing these groups?
>> We're digging into the group
organization, who's leading these
groups. The FBI, Homeland Security
Investigations, US Border Patrol are all
working in close concert. We're making
great strides in identifying the ring
leaders and we're going to bring them to
justice. And something else here is it's
not only federal agents and federal
property they're damaging, but they're
also going after American citizens whom
they might think are federal agents and
American citizens say driving an SUV.
They're actually stopping those citizens
on the highway damaging their vehicles,
slashing their tires. So it's not just
federal agents, it's everyday motans
that are feeling the pining from these
anarchists.
>> They're live streaming. I mean, they're
taking pride in what they're doing. I
mean, we want everybody across the
country to see it. Um, are you going to
keep using tear gas and pepper spray now
that this judge has come out and said
you can't use it against peaceful
protesters? I mean, some of these are
not peaceful.
>> Exactly. We're going to continue to use
that minimum amount of force necessary
to accomplish our mission. And we never
did use tear gas or any other less
lethal uh munitions against peaceful
protesters. We support the First
Amendment. We always support the First
Amendment, but they when they cross the
line and they're violent, we will use
those less lethal munitions because it
keeps them safe, it keeps our officers
safe, and it keeps the public safe.
>> So, we know that right now the DOJ is uh
in an active investigation of Mayor
Jacob Fry and the Minnesota Governor Tim
Walls. Um, and this is what Todd Blanch,
the US Deputy Attorney General, uh, told
our Matt Finn when he was asked about
the rhetoric from these two politicians.
Watch.
>> When the governor or the mayor threaten
our officers, when the mayor suggests
that he's encouraging
encouraging citizens to call 911 when
they see ICE officers, that is very
close to a federal crime.
>> I mean, this is what Governor Waltz this
week told residents. I mean, he was
telling them to film ICE. Let's listen
here.
>> I want to share another way you can
help. Witness. Help us establish a
record of exactly what's happening in
our communities. You have an absolute
right to peacefully film ICE agents as
they conduct these activities. So carry
your phone with you at all times.
>> Well, there you go. There's permission
to show up at any activities that ICE
have underway. Greg, do you think that
this is directly the fault of the mayor
and the governor? what we're seeing on
the ground, the chaos that is just so
out of control in Minneapolis.
>> Absolutely, 100%. President Trump,
Secretary Gnome, and Todd Blanch are
spot on in investigating that. It should
that should be investigated. And
something else, Aisha, that we're seeing
is that rank and file of many of the
area police departments, including
Minneapolis Police Department. many of
their rank and file police officers are
coming up to our agents on the ground
saying, "Thank you for what you're
doing. We support you 100%." That's in
direct direct opposition to say a mayor
fry calling for cops to fight federal
agents. So, we've got the support of the
rank and file and the American public.
Uh, this mission is going to continue.
>> So, they want to help. I mean, they're
coming up to you and telling you that
they actually do want to help, but their
hands are tied.
Exactly. We've seen this in California
and Los Angeles. We saw this with
Chicago rank and file police officers.
And guess what? We're seeing it in
Minneapolis also. And to any of those
Minneapolis police officers, and I'm
hearing this is happening, that want to
join the US Border Patrol or ICE. We
welcome you with open arms. We support
you. We support you making American
cities like Minneapolis a safer place.
So, I'd be happy to meet personally with
those officers. uh that might be wanting
to join a law enforcement agency that
supports them.
>> Greg, how do you get a handle on this? I
mean, it feels like it's never ending
and it continues to get worse and worse
day by day as we go. I remember the
George Floyd riots. I was in the thick
of it all covering it for Fox and that
went on for about a year. I mean, where
is this headed?
>> Sure, Aisha, great question. Um, we do
hard things. Let's take a look in
history at say the Civil War in Abraham
Lincoln or the Revolutionary War in
George Washington. We have Trump doing
equally hard things as they did.
Remember the Civil War did not have a
lot of support at the beginning. Neither
did George Washington in the
Revolutionary War, but they kept the
course. They did the right thing for MPA
America. That's what President Trump's
doing. We're going to continue this
course to rid this country of those vile
criminal illegal aliens that came across
the border by the millions over those
past four years. And we're on the right
track. What a righteous mission this is.
>> Yeah. The question that um our reporters
keep asking these protesters is who are
you protecting? I mean, who are you out
here? Name somebody that you're out here
defending that isn't on an ICE detainer.
Uh Greg, good to see you live live from
Minneapolis on the ground there uh with
Border Patrol. Thank you. Aisha, good to
see you. Thank you.
>> Hey, it's Will Kaine. Click here to
subscribe to the Fox News Channel on
YouTube. It's the best way to get our
latest interviews and highlights. and
click to subscribe to the Will Kane
podcast for full episodes right

transcript:
Joining me now is director of ICE Todd
Lions. Director, thanks very much for
being here this morning. I want you to
explain what has taken place here
because based on those comments that we
just saw from those Democrats, it feels
like the Democrats lit the match and now
they're trying to attack the agents who
are doing their job. I mean, let's face
it, these Democrats oversaw a wide open
border where some criminals came in. 350
people on the terrorist watch list were
encountered under Biden's years and then
they told citizens to get in the faces
of ICE when ICE reacted. Now they're
attacking ICE for doing their job. What
is taking place here? Please tell us.
>> Hey Mariam, thanks for having me. So
you're 100% right. So, we started seeing
this back in April and I, you know, I
sent up the flare and started asking,
you know, elected officials not to stoke
such dangerous rhetoric about ICE. And
now, exactly, you know, you are, you
know, seeing exactly what you just said.
You've seen the tax on ICE officers and
our other federal partners for only
going out there and doing their law
enforcement mission. We went to
Minnesota on that criminal fraud case
over $9 billion that, you know, Homeland
Security Investigations and the FBI were
investigating. At the same time, we had
more than 470 criminally illegal aliens
this year alone since President Trump
took office re-released back into the
communities. So, we were out there
focused on getting the worst of the
worst. And if you look at our social
media sites and see our press releases,
you'll see consistently ICE agents and
deportation officers have arrested
murderers, gang members, serial rapists,
people wanted from their home country
for heinous crimes. Yet, unfortunately,
you don't hear that. are automatically
assuming from uh elected officials that
ICE is out there doing something wrong.
And it's horrible for the fact that
people say that ICE is now targeting US
citizens. That's not the case. We have
to send more officers and agents just to
protect the men and women that are out
there trying to do their regular lawful
law enforcement mission.
>> Is there a better way for you to
communicate your priorities? In other
words, that priority is taking down
criminals in this country who are
committing crime who first committed the
first crime of illegally coming into the
country but then have gone on to commit
other crimes because the narrative that
the Democrats are are sending out there
is that ICE is going down breaking up
families taking people who are working
hard having people get a be afraid to go
to work. tell us your priorities and can
you prove to us that in fact your ICE
agents are out there taking down
criminality?
>> 100%. Maria, if you go ahead and you
look at what we've done since January
20th, you know, 70% of all illegal
aliens that ICE has arrested last year
and going into this calendar year have
criminal convictions or pending criminal
charges or warrants or criminal
histories back in their home country.
And you know, we've been focused on
those that have been lawfully ordered,
deported by an immigration judge who
failed to leave. So there's about 1.5
billion individuals in the country that
have been legally and lawfully ordered,
deported, or removed from this country
by a federal judge. Unfortunately, as
much press as we do, as many releases as
we put out, it just no one will pick up
the fact that we are actually out there
focused on our law enforcement mission.
And the one thing we say all the time
is, you know, these sanctuary
jurisdictions, you would not see this
many ICE agents and special agents on
the street focused on the criminal
illegal alien mission if they would just
turn people over to us. That's the key.
These local law enforcement agencies
have already deemed these individuals a
public safety threat and arrested them.
Why not work with federal partners, turn
them over to us, and let us get them out
of our communities? Well, I mean, I'm
I'm I'm wondering if all of these
attacks on our ICE agents have changed
the way these agents are doing their
job. Um, what can you tell us about
that? Is this stopping ICE agents or
changing the way they're doing their
jobs in any way because they're worried
that they're going to be under attack
when they get in the middle of a
situation?
>> You know, Maria, you're you're right in
the fact that it does change the mindset
of the men and women of ICE. Um, you
know, but that's why we have to provide
them so much support. You know, you you
hear about the 3,000 federal officers
and special agents that deployed to
Minneapolis. Majority of those, if not
most, are to protect the men and women
that are out there trying to make those
arrests. And that has definitely changed
our tactics where we would go and have
five to six officers on an arrest team.
Now, you have to go with 10 to 15 just
to protect those individuals that are
trying to arrest a bad guy. In my 30
years of law enforcement, I never
thought we would have to send law
enforcement to protect law enforcement.
But I don't think you'd see as many of
the issues if political leaders were
allowed their local and state law
enforcement to work with us. Great
point. It's it's Yeah, it's never a
public safety issue to uh pit law
enforcement against each other.
>> Of course. Really great point. Todd
Lions, thanks very much for being here
with us. ICE director Todd Lions this
morning. Thank you.
>> Hey, it's Will Kaine. Click here to
subscribe to the Fox News Channel on
YouTube. It's the best way to get our
latest interviews and highlights. and
click to subscribe to the Will Kane
podcast for full episodes right

House Majority Whip Rep. Tom Emmer, R-Minn., joins ‘Fox & Friends Weekend’ to discuss the latest on the unrest in Minneapolis as DHS deploys additional federal agents to the city. #foxnews #news #TomEmmer #Minneapolis #ICE #DHS #protests #immigration #politics #lawandorder #breakingnews #federalagents #ICEshooting #Minnesota #nationalnewsvideo 

Don’t just watch Fox News—be part of it. Become a Fox News Patriot today. https://youtube.com/foxnews/join

Subscribe to Fox News: https://bit.ly/2vBUvAS
Watch more Fox News Video: http://video.foxnews.com
Watch Fox News Channel Live: http://www.foxnewsgo.com/
Download the Fox News app: https://foxnews.onelink.me/xLDS/cd5yhg3o

FOX News Channel (FNC) is a 24-hour all-encompassing news service delivering breaking news as well as political and business news. The number one network in cable, FNC has been the most-watched television news channel for 18 consecutive years. According to a 2020 Brand Keys Consumer Loyalty Engagement Index report, FOX News is the top brand in the country for morning and evening news coverage. A 2019 Suffolk University poll named FOX News as the most trusted source for television news or commentary, while a 2019 Brand Keys Emotion Engagement Analysis survey found that FOX News was the most trusted cable news brand. A 2017 Gallup/Knight Foundation survey also found that among Americans who could name an objective news source, FOX News was the top-cited outlet. Owned by FOX Corporation, FNC is available in nearly 90 million homes and dominates the cable news landscape, routinely notching the top ten programs in the genre.

title: Protesters STORM Minneapolis hotel where ICE agents believed to be staying

The number one network in cable, FNC has been the most-watched television news channel for 18 consecutive years. According to a 2020 Brand Keys Consumer Loyalty Engagement Index report, FOX News is the top brand in the country for morning and evening news coverage. A 2019 Suffolk University poll named FOX News as the most trusted source for television news or commentary, while a 2019 Brand Keys Emotion Engagement Analysis survey found that FOX News was the most trusted cable news brand. A 2017 Gallup/Knight Foundation survey also found that among Americans who could name an objective news source, FOX News was the top-cited outlet. The number one network in cable, FNC has been the most-watched television news channel for 18 consecutive years. According to a 2020 Brand Keys Consumer Loyalty Engagement Index report, FOX News is the top brand in the country for morning and evening news coverage. A 2019 Suffolk University poll named FOX News as the most trusted source for television news or commentary, while a 2019 Brand Keys Emotion Engagement Analysis survey found that FOX News was the most trusted cable news brand. A 2017 Gallup/Knight Foundation survey also found that among Americans who could name an objective news source, FOX News was the top-cited outlet. jurisdiction. But again, at this point
in time, it does not appear that that is
the case. When there is an assault on a
federal officer, that is under title 18
US code section 111. And that gives the
FBI primary jurisdiction to conduct
these investigations. And my question
is, why are they all of the sudden the
Minnesota, you know, law enforcement and
Tim Walsh is out there, you know, having
a a huge fuss about this? All of a
sudden they want to work with the feds.
They've never wanted to work with the
feds. So all of a sudden they want to
work jointly with the FBI. Where have
they been all of this time? They've
never wanted to work with the feds. But
now when it comes to potentially
investigating an ICE agent, they are all
over wanting to work with the feds. And
if they think that the FBI cannot see
that, they absolutely can. Well, and
that's exactly what's so perplexing,
Nicole, is why the state wants to be
part of investigation after they've
already prejudged this ICE agent as
guilty. Some calling him a murderer.
Here's a little bit of Governor Walls
and Mayor Fry. Listen here. We've been
warning for weeks that the Trump
administration's dangerous,
sensationalized operations are a threat
to our public safety, that someone was
going to get hurt. We do not need any
further help from the federal
government.
To Donald Trump and Christy Gnome,
you've done enough. What ICE is doing is
terrorizing our community. If we're
talking about what's inflammatory, on
the one hand, you got someone who
dropped an Fbomb and on the other hand,
you got someone who killed somebody
else.
So why do the locals want to be part of
this investigation when they are grossly
biased in their approach to whether or
not ICE is at fault here?
>> Again, based on my experience in working
investigations, if there had been a
local officer involved in this shooting,
I could understand why they might, you
know, step in. And I have worked jointly
with other local jurisdictions when it
involves the feds and the locals. But in
this instance, there was no level. They
they did not even want to be there. this
is a sanctuary city. They would not even
provide assistance or backup. The locals
would not even help the feds. And so all
of a sudden, they want this level of
cooperation and to work jointly and they
want to see the evidence. And again,
let's let the FBI conduct their full
investigation. Let's see where the chips
fall. Having been an FBI special agent
who worked violent crime. This is very
serious. They will be looking at the
level of what the agent's perception was
at the time that this incident occurred.
Did the agent have reasonable belief
that the subject posed imminent danger
of death or serious physical injury to
themselves or to another person? Agents
are expected to make split-second
decisions. It's action versus reaction.
It comes down to life or death. And for
anyone to think that a vehicle cannot be
a deadly weapon. It absolutely can.
>> Yeah. And the agent involved here has 10
plus years experience on the force, part
of the ERRO's elite SRT team. unclear
whether the fed or the locals would give
it a fair hearing. Nicole Parker, thank
you very much. And make sure to check
out her book, The Two FBI's. It's
available now. Thank you, Nicole.
>> Thank you.
>> Fox has learned the woman killed in an
ICE involved shooting in Minneapolis was
an activist who was part of the ICE
watch effort across the city. Here's
Vice President Vance. Listen,
>> you see just with this most recent
terrible incident in Minneapolis, you
see friends of this woman's or other
people who are eyewitnesses saying
basically that she was there to engage
in obstruction of a legitimate law
enforcement operation. How did she get
there? How did she learn about this?
There's an entire network and frankly
some of the media are participating in
it that is trying to incite violent
against our law enforcement officers.
>> Left-wing groups here mobilizing across
the city. Let's bring in Cal
Schneiderler, director for Homeland
Security and Counterterrorism at the
Center for Security Policy. Cal, who is
this group, ICE Watch, and how are they
funded?
>> Well, I think uh the vice president is
absolutely correct to describe this as a
left-wing ecosystem. The reality is that
there are these ICE watch groups in
almost every uh major blue city in the
country where we are seeing these
standoffs between ICE and these
community organization protesters. Uh
and it's actually not that difficult for
these groups to be stood up. Uh you can
find instructions on how to start one of
these groups on the web. uh everything
down to how to use the tactics to block
in uh block in ICE patrols with your
vehicles, how to identify ICE vehicles,
how to track and monitor them, how to
use uh signal encryption and similar
apps uh to share information with other
participants. So the standing up of
these groups is actually not that
challenging. Uh and what is what is
challenging is the training and the
organizing that goes on behind it. the
large national groups uh that know how
to put on a major protest, that know how
to lead people down this path of
radicalization. When the vice president
described uh this woman in Minneapolis
as a victim of that ecosystem, I think
he's right. Also, uh there are people
who are being led into very dangerous
situations um confronting federal law
enforcement, not realizing uh the threat
that that poses. And there are
organizations uh revolutionary
organizations that seek to take
advantage uh when those people are
harmed or killed. And that's what we're
seeing today with uh groups mobilizing
across the country like Party for
Socialism and Liberation, organizing
protests across multiple cities, right?
Uh target this event.
>> And Cal, so we're learning uh Fox has
learned from DHS sources that Renee Good
was an immigration activist. She was
part of this ICE watch. They she was
trained to track, monitor, and interfere
in ICE operations. We're also learning
that she visited at least two other ICE
locations with her car blocking ICE
prior to her her shooting. So, she
clearly was trying to do more than be a
legal observer. She was inserting
herself into ICE operations. My question
is, who is paying for this?
Well, that term legal observer is
interesting because you see it being
thrown around a lot. I think most
Americans don't realize that that is
very coded language. These legal
observers are trained protest
organizers. Uh most often when you see
that term legal observer, it's referring
to groups from the National Lawyers
Guild. That's a longtime communist party
organization that organizes the legal
support for vast uh variety of protests.
uh everything from protests to Antifa to
legitimate terrorist groups uh all get
national lawyers guild support. So I
don't think the American people should
be fooled when they hear that term a
legal observer. All it's really telling
you is that this woman was a
professional protester.
>> Well, and I think it is important that
we follow the money on this one because
these groups are growing from California
to Illinois now in Minneapolis. Cal
Schneiderler, thank you for taking time.
Have a good day.
>> Thank you. US Border Patrol Chief Greg
Bavino is here reacting to all of this.
Uh it's great to see you. Um officer
officer Bavino, am I is that correct or
agent?
>> Asian. Okay. Well, Agent Bavino, it's
great to see you here. It was
interesting to be on the ground today at
the what they call as a vigil and it
seemed like it was a community
gathering. It seemed pretty pro. I mean,
they they don't like us, but fine, but
it seemed fairly peaceful. Although,
man, they policed their border pretty
well there. I mean, they don't they
don't like anyone in their area that
doesn't agree with them, which I found
interesting.
>> Oh, well, Laura, thanks for having me
tonight. But it's very interesting how
intolerant some of those individuals are
when you talk about them policing their
own border. We see that quite often, as
you know, out in the streets here in
Minneapolis, Chicago, Los Angeles, New
Orleans, Charlotte, all those places
we've been, we see exactly what you're
talking about.
>> Well, illegal aliens have every right to
be here, but conservatives have no right
to be here. I mean, that's basically it.
>> That's exactly that's what they're
saying. That is what they are saying.
This violent rhetoric, whether it's a
Tim Waltz, uh, Newsome, a Pritser, that
is what they're saying is they're
choosing those illegal aliens over
American citizens and over American law
enforcement is reprehensible. I was told
that um yesterday and I was told this
today by a a 26-year veteran of of the
Secret Service that he has never seen a
time where state and local officials had
not supported the visit of a cabinet
secretary to this state and yesterday
there was no support of the visit of
Christine Gnome who came to address the
the horrible tragedy of yesterday. Is
that is that surprising to you? I mean
you all usually work together. It's
always surprising state and local law
enforcement and federal law enforcement
have traditionally worked together on a
myriad of missions. Whether it's
protecting a cabinet level member coming
or that local law enforcement effort
helping us. They've always supported us,
but we don

FOX News Channel (FNC) is a 24-hour all-encompassing news service delivering breaking news as well as political and business news. The number one network in cable, FNC has been the most-watched television news channel for 18 consecutive years. According to a 2020 Brand Keys Consumer Loyalty Engagement Index report, FOX News is the top brand in the country for morning and evening news coverage. A 2019 Suffolk University poll named FOX News as the most trusted source for television news or commentary, while a 2019 Brand Keys Emotion Engagement Analysis survey found that FOX News was the most trusted cable news brand. A 2017 Gallup/Knight Foundation survey also found that among Americans who could name an objective news source, FOX News was the top-cited outlet. Owned by FOX Corporation, FNC is available in nearly 90 million homes and dominates the cable news landscape, routinely notching the top ten programs in the genre.

A 2019 Suffolk University poll named FOX News as the most trusted source for television news or commentary, while a 2019 Brand Keys Emotion Engagement Analysis survey found that FOX News was the most trusted cable news brand. transcript:
Protesters for and against the Trump
administration's ICE crackdown clashed
in Minneapolis Saturday as Governor Tim
Walls prepared to mobilize his state's
National Guard troops to assist local
law enforcement as the Washington Post
is reporting the Pentagon is preparing
active duty soldiers for a possible
deployment to Minnesota. In a moment,
we're going to bring in Deputy Attorney
General Todd Blanch. But first, Fox News
correspondent Matt Finn is in
Minneapolis. Matt
>> and Shannon. The Washington Post reports
about 1,500 active duty soldiers are
prepared to possibly head here to
Minnesota if the violence escalates. And
yesterday it was another day of some
pretty intense clashes.
Unrest showing no signs of slowing down
in the Twin Cities. Persistent
protesters even lit fires for warmth on
a snowy Friday night outside of the ICE
detention center. Hours earlier, inside
US Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanch,
telling immigration agents the DOJ will
go after anyone who lays a finger on
them.
>> My marching orders from President Trump
all the way on down, Attorney General
Bondi all the way on down, is that every
single time that happens, we will
prosecute.
>> In a special state address this week,
Governor Walls telling people to collect
evidence against ICE. All across
Minnesota, people are learning about
opportunities not just to resist, but to
help people who are in danger.
>> The DOJ is now investigating Walls and
Fry for possibly impeding immigration
enforcement. Mayor Fry says the probe is
meant to intimidate him. Governor Walls,
writing, "The only person not being
investigated for the shooting of Renee
Good is the federal agent who shot her."
outraged Democrats alleged DHS agents
are racially profiling and violating
civil rights.
>> For the moment, we can certainly block
giving additional funding to ICE and
CBP.
>> And Shannon, here in Minnesota, anti-ICE
activists have scheduled a statewide day
of action for this Friday. They're
asking people not to go to work, not to
go to school, and not to make purchases.
Shannon.
>> All right, Matt Finn reporting from
Minneapolis. Matt, thank you to you and
your team there on the ground. And
joining us now, Deputy Attorney General
Todd Blanch. Thanks for your time this
morning.
>> Good morning.
>> Okay, so let's start here. I want to
play a little bit more of what
Congresswoman Jipal had to say uh about
what she says is actually happening on
the ground there in Minneapolis.
We are seeing horrifying videos of ICE
agents battering down people's doors
without a warrant, racially profiling
people on the street, busting in car
windows, and trying to intimidate and
suppress the First Amendment rights to
peacefully protest.
>> So my question is, is she inaccurate the
way she's mischaracterizing or is she
mischaracterizing what's happening
there? Or is that actually happening?
But the argument is ICE has the
authority to do what they're doing.
Yeah, what what what you just heard was
a complete lie. That is absolutely not
is what's happening on the ground in
Minnesota. I was there on Friday. I saw
what the men and women of ICE are doing
every day and they are doing their job.
And and there are folks that may not
like that they're doing their job, but
these these blatant accusations that
they're violating the the First
Amendment or somehow committing crimes
are not only completely false, but
they're doing real damage to our law
enforcement officers around the country.
And it's interesting that there are
thousands of immigration actions all
over this country every single day and
nowhere do you hear this outrage this
this madeup outrage from local
politicians and activists except for in
Minnesota and and that should be telling
to the American people.
>> So they have you know those who are
protesting and supporting the protesters
took this to court. A federal judge on
Friday late ruled that there are a
number of things agents cannot do. Now,
part of what she said is they can't use
pepper spray or similar non-lethal
munitions on these crowds. She does
reference them being engaged in peaceful
and unobstructive protest activity. She
also says you can't stop stop or detain
drivers or passengers in vehicles where
there's no reasonable articulable
suspicion that they're actually
obstructing or interfering. She goes on
to say, you know, if they're following
and tagging and filming ICE, that is not
something that is a stoppable uh issue.
So, how does this impact operations
there? and are you going to appeal that
decision?
>> We're still looking at whether to appeal
what that judge did at this point. But
I'll tell you, it's absurd for the the
the media and and some of these
politicians to call what these folks are
doing as peaceful protests. They're
throwing rocks at ICE officers. They are
standing in the roadway where they try
to drive by. They're putting their
vehicles in the roadway while they try
to drive by. So if a judge tells ICE
officers not to vi violate the
constitutional rights of protesters, we
got it. We're not violating the
constitutional rights. But what should
be happening instead of going after ICE
officers, what should be happening is
local leaders should be sending law
enforcement out to stop the protesters
from assaulting ICE officers for doing
nothing except for their job. And that's
that's the real issue here is you have
you have men and women who have families
going out and doing exactly what they're
supposed to do and being screamed at,
pushed, assaulted, having rocks thrown
at them. We will not tolerate that and
that that's that's been our position
from the beginning and it will remain
our position for the rest of this
administration.
>> Okay. So Friday we also learned that the
DOJ is reportedly investigating Governor
Walls, uh, Mayor Fry there. Um, they
have both responded. Here's what we
heard from the mayor on Friday. He said,
"It's an obvious attempt to intimidate
me for standing up for Minneapolis, our
local law enforcement, and our residents
against the chaos and danger this
administration has brought to our
streets." He says, "I will not be
intimidated." What can you tell us about
the investigation and the perception or
accusation that you all are weaponizing
law enforcement against these folks?
You saw the governor and the mayor
actively encouraging encouraging
criminals to go out on the street and
impede ICE. That is not allowed under
our law. When a federal officer is out
doing their job, they have to be allowed
to do their jobs. And the fact that we
had to stand up and tell a mayor that we
had to stand up and tell a governor to
stop encouraging the folks that are that
are out there running around trying to
stop ICE to stop encouraging them when
what they really should be doing is
helping their fellow federal officers is
something that's that's horrible. But
listen, no matter who you are, whether
you're a governor, a mayor, or or
somebody out there on the streets
assaulting ICE, you cannot under federal
law, you cannot impede a federal officer
doing their job. And that that's that's
what we're looking at. And and I'm not
going to talk about the investigation,
but but American people can can see what
the mayor has been saying. They can see
what the governor's been saying, and
it's obvious that that has to stop.
>> Well, the governor's response referenced
a number of things. um you know going
after Mark Kelly, he says Alyssa
Slackin, Jerome Powell, but he also
mentioned what Matt Finn uh mentioned in
his reporting there. He says the only
person not being investigated for the
shooting of Renee Good is the federal
agent who shot her. So is the FBI con
conducting investigation into that agent
into the shooting? What can you tell us
about that? Will it be made public?
Look, what happened on that day has been
reviewed by millions and millions of
Americans because it was recorded on on
phones um when it happened. Okay? The
civil rights, the Department of Justice,
our civil rights unit, we don't just go
out and investigate every time an
officer is is is forced to defend
himself against somebody or putting his
life in danger. We never do. That has
nothing to do with what happened in
Minne Minneapolis. There are over a
thousand shootings every year where law
enforcement are put in danger by
individuals and they have to protect
themselves and they have a lawful right
to do so. The Department of Justice just
doesn't just stand up and investigate
because some congressman thinks we
should, because some governor thinks
that we should. We investigate when it's
appropriate to investigate. And that is
not the case here. It wasn't the case
when it happened and it's not the case
today. If circumstances change and
there's something that we do need to
investigate around that shooting or any
other shooting, we will. But but we are
not going to bow to pressure from the
media, bout of pressure from politicians
and do something that we never do. Not
under this administration, not under the
last administration. And so, no, we we
are not investigating. And if if if
there comes a time when we need to, we
will. But it's not now.
>> Is there some type of internal review
though that happens when someone dies at
the hands of an agent? Of
course. I mean, every law enforcement
agency has has their own protocols when
an officer is required to defend
themselves. Every single law enforcement
agency, even the Minnesota Police
Department in Minneapolis, and so does
DHS, and so does the FBI, and so does
every state police department. And so,
of course, there's an investigation
that's happening, but that's a big
difference from what you have the
governor insisting that this civil
rights unit do and this Department of
Justice do. And and we are not going to
do that. Okay, let's talk about the
insurrection act. Uh the president
sounds like I mean he's talked about it
possibly being used in a number of
situations and specifically there in
Minnesota. It sounds like he's standing
down or at least saying he doesn't think
it's necessary at this point, but we've
got the Washington Post reporting that
some 1500 active duty troops, the
Pentagon's put them on standby
potentially to deploy into this
situation. Um no surprise that the
attorney general there in Minnesota,
Keith Ellison, has said he'll go
straight to court over this if you
decide to sue. Um he also has already
filed a separate uh lawsuit saying this.
He says the threat suggests that the
federal government is attempting to
create a pretext for military deployment
by provoking civil unrest. Your
response?
>> Well, President Trump has promised to
keep the American people safe and the
fact that the local law enforcement
because their leadership is not doing
their jobs. There may come a time when
the president has to order that. And we
support him. the attorney general
supports him because we have to keep the
citizens safe. Now, in cities across
this country, in all 50 states, that's
done by local law enforcement and
leadership. Unfortunately, in
Minneapolis, those local law
enforcement, who I'm sure are great men
and women are being ordered to stand
down. And so, when the American people,
when the the citizens of Minnesota are
threatened by what's happening there,
you better believe President Trump's
going to be there for them. He promised,
he campaigned on that. He won the
election on that. and and if he sees
what's happening continue, that's that's
an available tool to make sure that that
American citizens stay safe.
>> All right, just to clarify a couple of
things. You say local law enforcement's
being told to stand down. Is that in in
response to attacks on ICE, these
situations? You're saying the locals are
not showing up. They're not controlling
the situation.
>> Local leadership told citizens to call
911 when they see ICE. They did not tell
lo did they did not tell citizens to
call 911 when they see ICE officers
being assaulted and attacked. And to the
contrary, police officers are not
anywhere to be seen around the ICE
facilities. When the ICE officers are
out doing the work they have to do,
there are no cops around. And that is
not that is not the way that it that it
takes place in cities across this
country. In virtually every place we go
in, we get support from law enforcement
because that's their job. And again,
this is not an indictment of the of the
men and women who are police officers in
that city. This is an indictment of the
leadership that's telling them what to
do. And that's why President Trump is
looking at all available options and
will continue to do so because the local
leadership is not letting local law
enforcement do their jobs.
>> All right, Deputy Attorney General Todd
Blanch, thanks for your time today.
>> Thank you very much.
>> Hey, it's Will Kaine. Click here to
subscribe to the Fox News Channel on
YouTube. It's the best way to get our
latest interviews and highlights.

title: Acting ICE director responds to Minneapolis mayor’s ICE claim: ‘RIDICULOUS’

transcript:
Joining us now with some answers to the
questions that a lot of you have, ICE
director Todd Lions. Todd, thank you for
being back.
>> Thanks, Peter. Good seeing you.
>> So, let's start in Portland where the
police chief was crying while admitting
that two illegal immigrants who were
shot by ICE this week have ties to Trend
Ara, TDA.
It saddens me that we even have to
qualify um these remarks
because I understand or at least have
attempted to understand through your
voices your concern, your fear, your
anger.
>> Director Lions, what's he crying about?
>> You know, [clears throat] Peter, I I
have no idea what he's crying about. you
know, border patrol agents were
conducting a targeted enforcement
operation on suspected TDA gang members
in a human trafficking prostitute and
staying in his city. So, I would think
he would be happy that we take these
criminal elements out of his
neighborhoods, but I'm not sure what
he's crying about. Uh, he went on to say
that he didn't want to victim blame.
There's there were criminals in this
situation, not victims. And if you use a
3 to 4,000lb vehicle to attempt to ram a
law enforcement officer, whether it's
one of his officers, state police, or
border patrol agent, there's going to be
consequences. And we're happy that we're
taking two TDA gang members, which TDA
is a known suspected terrorist
organization now, out of the community.
And moving on to Minneapolis, there's
this video that most people watching and
have seen, but we are going to put it up
on the screen. It's the officer's point
of view taken by an iPhone. He's got an
iPhone in one hand and a gun in the
other hand. Why no body cam?
So, we're still in the process of
deploying body cameras for all law
enforcement officers. Unfortunately, in
the last administration, we didn't have
the funding. Only our special response
team had that. But the officer made that
decision, his team, that they were going
to arrest agitators that day. That's why
he was recording. You know, as you can
see in that video, he was documenting
the license plate, documenting the area,
and he wasn't standing in front of that
vehicle. he was going around to the
driver's door where the other officer
was attempting to make that arrest when
unfortunately that incident happened.
So, you know, a split-second decision on
his part. You know, he had a driver's
weapon while he was still filming um and
his training kicked in. But again, if
you if a civilian puts himself in this
situation and you get involved in a law
enforcement operation, it's just not
smart and tragedies happen.
>> There is some new math coming out of
Minneapolis this weekend courtesy of the
mayor, Jacob Fry.
50% of the shootings that have happened
thus far in Minneapolis this year have
been ICE. In other words, we've only had
two shootings.
One of them has been ICE.
We are a safe city. ICE is making it
less so. We are a city of unity, but ICE
is trying to divide us and tear us
apart.
>> Director Lions, it's a small sample
size, but what do you say about that?
Mayor Frey saying half the shootings are
you guys.
>> You know, uh to me that's just again
that this heated political rhetoric that
just doesn't need to be. Um you know, no
law enforcement officer wants to be
involved in any type of deadly force
situation. And like I've always said
since the beginning of this, you know,
our hearts and minds and prayers go out
to all that were involved in the
situation. But to categorically,
you know, say that more than half of the
shootings are now because of us, that's
ridiculous. And to your point about the
rhetoric, lawmakers in Washington never
like to let a good crisis go to waste.
There have been a lot of hot takes in
the last couple days like this one.
>> I understand that Vice President Vance
believes that shooting a young mother of
three in the face three times is an
acceptable America that he wants to live
in. And I do not. And that is a
fundamental difference uh between Vice
President Vance and I. I do not believe
that the American people um should be
assassinated in the street. A lot of
Democrats say that they think that is
what happened, that this woman was
assassinated in the street. What do you
say to them?
>> So, what I just say to them is obviously
look at the video, look at the
situation. Um, it wasn't an
assassination. That law enforcement
officer had milliseconds, if not short
time, to make a decision to save his
life and his other fellow agents. So, it
wasn't an assassination. And again, you
know, I think a lot of the political
rhetoric is where we're at right now in
the first place. There's just so much
attacks on ICE, you know, and
unfortunately it does come from a lot of
elected officials. We would much rather
work with elected officials to hold
individuals accountable that are doxing
agents, threatening agents, etc. But
instead for, you know, elected officials
to call upon the impeachment of ICE to
resist ICE, that just only stokes these
fires and gets these individuals who who
aren't, you know, trying to do the right
thing when it comes to ICE, gets them
fired up more. And Democrats keep
claiming that your officers are
terrorizing their cities. In
Minneapolis, a city council member is
actually saying now city leadership is
exploring every possible avenue to end
ICE activity in Minneapolis. Can they do
that?
No, Peter, they can't. And you know,
everyone keeps saying about ICE out of
Minnesota. That ICE has been in
Minnesota since the inception of DHS and
even before that under DOJ with when we
were INS. So, we've always been
conducting immigration enforcement in
all 50 states, but I always go back to
say we wouldn't be out on the street if
local jurisdictions worked with us to
turn over these crimally illegal aliens
once they are already considered a
public safety threat by the locals. Just
turn them over to us in a safe, secure
environment. And you wouldn't have to
have us going out and arresting these
folks. But, you know, we did just
release that list of the worst of the
worst that we arrested. You know, we
arrested someone that fled the state of
Connecticut on a warrant for a rape of a
child to hide in plain sight in
Minneapolis. And he was also wanted for
murder in his home country. So, I would
think people would be happy and excited
that those are the individuals were
taken off the streets. I don't know why
anybody in their right mind would
champion that type of individual. And
before we let you go, Director Lions, I
talked to President Trump this week
about an alleged organized crime
conspiracy to hurt ICE officers.
What has your team told you about this
broad left-wing network? Who is in
charge of it? Who's part of it? What
what's it called?
>> Well, I haven't seen the vice
president's statement, but he's
generally very accurate. I hate to say
it. Uh, look, uh, I watched that
yesterday, and there are a lot of lot of
different forms to it, but there was a
woman screaming shame, shame, shame,
shame. She was a agitator, probably a
paid agitator, but in my opinion, she
was an agitator. a very high level
agitator.
>> Director Lions, what have you been told
about this left-wing network the White
House is talking about that is
threatening ICE officers nationwide?
>> Well, Peter, ICE, uh, you know, Homeland
Security Investigations and the FBI,
we're actively investigating many groups
all across the US now that are actively
targeting ICE officers and agents and
other federal partners in their
day-to-day mission. So, we do believe
there's a c criminal conspiracy going
on. We are working with all of our
federal partners to try to track down
the funding, the leadership of these
groups because you know we would see
time and time again ICE officers and
agents would be doing an operation and
within seconds to minutes all of a
sudden there's 50 60 protesters on that
site. So there's an active active group
out there that is criminally based
that's you know impeding and causing
these operations in.
>> All right, Director Todd Lions, thank
you very much for being here.
>> Great seeing you Peter. Thank you.
>> Click here to subscribe to the Fox News
YouTube page to catch our hottest
interviews and most compelling analysis.
You won't get it anywhere else.
