All right, this is a Fox News alert.
This breaking just as we come on the air
tonight, we have learned that there was
an ICE involved shooting in Minneapolis.
Uh we go live to Alexis McAdams. She is
live on the ground with the details. Uh
Alexis, I' I've just been looking at
these images that we're just getting a
hold of now and we'll keep them up for
our audience to see. It looks like
things are, you know, spiraling out of
control very quickly there.
>> Well, Sean, that's the thing is it es
and flows. So, one minute, you know,
there's a small protest at the federal
building. The next minute, these people
with whistles and an agenda show up to
these different sites across the city.
That's what DHS has been saying. What we
know right now from our colleague Bill
Malusian, who just got off the phone
with this federal sources, Sean, is that
a man who was a target of an ICE
operation from Venezuela, who ICE says
was in the country illegally, was a
target in this operation here in
Minnesota. So, they go to the door.
That's when they say this Venezuelan
migrant held up a shovel, tried to
assault one of their agents. And you can
hear those chants there in the
background as protesters show up. That's
when they say used the shovel to try and
assault the agent. Shots were fired.
This Venezuelan teen, we're told, was
shot in the lake, expected to be okay.
Bill Malusian telling me there's
actually a picture that a source texted
him of this guy on a stretcher smiling,
kind of giving a thumbs up as he's taken
away to the hospital. So, we'll get more
on what's going on there at the scene.
But, it's become aggressive here and I
saw it today when I was on the ground
with law enforcement here with ICE
agents here in Minnesota. It's something
we've been keeping an eye on as it
continues to grow. But it comes as the
governor here, Tim Walls, who's also
under investigation in this huge fraud
scheme here, Sean, just told people,
"Hey, these are just our neighbors. And
if you see them getting arrested, take
out your cell phone and record. Watch."
>> Armed, masked, undertrained ICE agents
are going door to door ordering people
to point out where their neighbors of
color live. They're pulling over people
indiscriminately,
including US citizens, and demanding to
see their papers. And if you see these
ICE agents in your neighborhood, take
out that phone and hit record. Help us
create a database of the atrocities
against motans.
>> But that's just not what we saw today on
the streets of Minneapolis. You can see
the protesters are continuing to erupt
here with anger. But when you talk to
ICE agents, they say that they're being
doxed, they're being tracked, and
they're being targeted here. We saw it
when before they even got out of the car
today at some of these crime scenes.
These people were out notifying law
enforcement. Take a look at this.
>> And then also, we can tell you that the
tactic though is not new here in the
streets of Minneapolis. It's been
rampant. Borders are Tom Hman telling
Fox earlier the White House is actually
looking into who these protesters you
see on your screen are. Uh you can see
the pepper balls. You can see the pepper
spray being shot and this is what
continues to happen. Sean, uh you know,
we can tell you it's been a week since
Renee Nicole Good was shot here in the
streets of Minneapolis. But ICE says
they're not pulling out. This is
targeted operation.
>> Hey, Sean Hannity here. Hey, click here

transcript:
Anti-ICE protests erupting this weekend
over the shooting of a Minnesota woman
by an ICE officer. As DHS Secretary
Gnome defends her domestic terrorism
assessment,
>> if you look at what the definition of
domestic terrorism is, it completely
fits this individual. As you saw in the
video that we released just 48 hours
after this incident, uh showed that this
officer was hit by her vehicle. She
weaponized it and he defended his life
and those colleagues around him.
So DHS saying new video of the moments
beforehand proves Renee Good was quote
stalking and impeding a law enforcement
operation all morning as additional
video shows how it went down from the
officer's point of view. Watch.
>> You want to come at us? You want to come
at us? I say go get yourself some lunch,
big boy. Go ahead.
Get out of the car. Get out OF THE CAR.
FOX NEWS LEGAL ANALYST Greg Jared joins
us now. So Greg, uh, weigh in here. I I
saw on the Sunday shows, they really
took this on about the the Secretary of
Homeland Security's words and that quote
domestic terrorism. This is actually a
legal term that has been debated for
years. What is your view on the
situation here?
>> Well, Lawrence, domestic terrorism is
actually defined as violence by
individuals or groups driven by extreme
political ideologies to try to affect
government conduct through coercion,
criminal acts, and you know, a vehicle
is a deadly weapon. And if you weaponize
it to harm a federal officer, if you're
doing it uh because you politically
disagree with ICE enforcing the law,
then sure. I mean, it could be described
as domestic terrorism. Look at the
database. It's filled with cases
involving vehicles as domestic
terrorism. And you know, in the end,
there's really no excuse under the law
for resisting or fleeing law enforcement
and accelerating your SUV with an
officer either of in front of it or
perpendicular that puts him in harm's
way, triggering the law of self-defense.
And the legal test is whether this
officer at that moment reasonably
believed his life was in danger. If the
answer is yes, he does have a right to
use lethal force. And in fact, in
Minnesota, there's a specific law that
allows officers to use deadly force by
shooting at an oncoming vehicle. So, I
think the secretary may be correct here.
>> Do you think, and I'm just want to play
devil's advocate because this is
something that is highly debated right
now. It it is true just by the statue
alone, it looks like that the officer
acted according to the statute. The
Supreme Court has ruled on uh what
officers feel is imminent fear. It is
true that she impeded the officers and
they have footage of her doing it the
entire day, but how do you link that to
a broader uh push for domestic
terrorism? I think that's the part where
some people struggle.
Well, it goes down to the motive. Was
this done to be anti-govern
and to try to change the behavior of
ICE? And if the answer is yes, and
there's considerable evidence that that
was her motive, she was part of the
resistance involved in trying to
obstruct and block and hinder ICE, then
sure, that's domestic terrorism. Um, it
would be important if there was a
prosecution here. But of course, the
driver Renee Good is deceased. Although,
uh, you know, you heard the videotape in
which her wife was saying, "Drive, baby,
drive."
>> Right.
>> Well, that could be aiding and abetting
fleeing police with a domestic terrorism
motive. So, you know, it still is
relevant.
>> It's a good point. I want to get your
thoughts on another case. So, federal
prosecutors in Washington DC have opened
up a criminal probe into Fed Chair
Jerome Powell. Um, what is your thoughts
on this? Is there some standing here for
a case such like this?
>> Sure, there could be. Uh, you know, the
question is, did Powell lie to the
Senate Banking Committee about the costs
of renovations of two rather lavish
buildings? The overrun has been
staggering in the billions. Uh the irony
of course is the Fed blames inflation
for that. The question was you know was
Pal dishonest, deceptive,
um you know extravagant, lush amenities,
gardens, fountains, fancy marble, ornate
fixtures, luxury dining room. He denies
any of that, but there is evidence it
does exist. So the US attorney, which
began the probe a couple of months ago,
has now issued grand jury subpoenas. But
just because you do that doesn't mean
criminal charges will eventually ensue.
We'll wait and see.
>> He claims that it is government
retribution because he refuses to lower
the interest rate. Is that going to be a
credible defense for him?
>> Well, it could be under uh the the label
of, you know, uh retribution and
selective prosecution. is the sort of
thing that others like James Comey,
Leticia James have made in their
respective cases. So, it is a possible
defense here.
>> Copy that, Greg Jared. Thank you so
much.
>> I'm Steve Ducey. I'm Brian Kilme.
>> And I'm Anley Airheart. And click here
to subscribe to the Fox News YouTube
page to catch our hottest interviews and
most compelling analysis.

title: Minneapolis mayor DOUBLES DOWN on anti-ICE rhetoric: 'GET OUT'
description:
Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey joins 'Fox & Friends' to address his lawsuit aiming to block ICE operations, his criticisms of immigration enforcement agents in the city and allegations of fraud in his state.

#fox #media #breakingnews #us #usa #new #news #breaking #foxnews #foxandfriends #jacobfrey #frey #minneapolis #minnesota #ice #dhs #immigration #enforcement #lawsuit #courts #legal #constitution #unconstitutional #lawenforcement #police #crime #crimenews #crimestory #criminal #fraud #scandal #oversight #politics #political #politicalnews #government

Watch Fox News Channel Live: http://www.foxnewsgo.com/

Download the Fox News app: https://foxnews.onelink.me/xLDS/cd5yhg3o

FOX News Channel (FNC) is a 24-hour all-encompassing news service delivering breaking news as well as political and business news. The number one network in cable, FNC has been the most-watched television news channel for 18 consecutive years. According to a 2020 Brand Keys Consumer Loyalty Engagement Index report, FOX News is the top brand in the country for morning and evening news coverage. A 2019 Suffolk University poll named FOX News as the most trusted source for television news or commentary, while a 2019 Brand Keys Emotion Engagement Analysis survey found that FOX News was the most trusted cable news brand. A 2017 Gallup/Knight Foundation survey also found that among Americans who could name an objective news source, FOX News was the top-cited outlet. Owned by FOX Corporation, FNC is available in nearly 90 million homes and dominates the cable news landscape, routinely notching the top ten programs in the genre.

title: Minneapolis Mayor reveals whether he wants ICE abolished
description:
Mayor Jacob Frey discusses the presence of I.C.E. and protests in his city on 'Fox & Friends.' #fox #media #breakingnews #us #usa #new #news #breaking #foxnews #foxandfriends #politics #political #politicalnews #government #immigration #border #ice #protest #minneapolis #minnesota #mayor #constitution #lawenforcement #frey #jacobfrey

Don’t just watch Fox News—be part of it. Become a Fox News Patriot today. https://youtube.com/foxnews/join

Subscribe to Fox News: https://bit.ly/2vBUvAS
Watch more Fox News Video: http://video.foxnews.com
Watch Fox News Channel Live: http://www.foxnewsgo.com/
Download the Fox News app: https://foxnews.onelink.me/xLDS/cd5yhg3o

FOX News Channel (FNC) is a 24-hour all-encompassing news service delivering breaking news as well as political and business news. The number one network in cable, FNC has been the most-watched television news channel for 18 consecutive years. According to a 2020 Brand Keys Consumer Loyalty Engagement Index report, FOX News is the top brand in the country for morning and evening news coverage. A 2019 Suffolk University poll named FOX News as the most trusted source for television news or commentary, while a 2019 Brand Keys Emotion Engagement Analysis survey found that FOX News was the most trusted cable news brand. A 2017 Gallup/Knight Foundation survey also found that among Americans who could name an objective news source, FOX News was the top-cited outlet. Owned by FOX Corporation, FNC is available in nearly 90 million homes and dominates the cable news landscape, routinely notching the top ten programs in the genre.

title: ‘Hope we see mugshots soon’: DHS WARNS anti-ICE agitators
description:
DHS Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin discusses anti-ICE agitators storming a church in Minnesota and calls out Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey for his response to the illegal immigration crackdown.  #fox #media #breakingnews #us #usa #new #news #breaking #foxnews #foxreportweekend #politics #political #politicalnews #government #ice #immigration #minneapolis #protests #dhs #nancy-mace #church #publicsafety #america

Don’t just watch Fox News—be part of it. Become a Fox News Patriot today. https://youtube.com/foxnews/join
Subscribe to Fox News: https://bit.ly/2vBUvAS
Watch more Fox News Video: http://video.foxnews.com
Watch Fox News Channel Live: http://www.foxnewsgo.com/
Download the Fox News app: https://foxnews.onelink.me/xLDS/cd5yhg3o

FOX News Channel (FNC) is a 24-hour all-encompassing news service delivering breaking news as well as political and business news. The number one network in cable, FNC has been the most-watched television news channel for 18 consecutive years. According to a 2020 Brand Keys Consumer Loyalty Engagement Index report, FOX News is the top brand in the country for morning and evening news coverage. A 2019 Suffolk University poll named FOX News as the most trusted source for television news or commentary, while a 2019 Brand Keys Emotion Engagement Analysis survey found that FOX News was the most trusted cable news brand. A 2017 Gallup/Knight Foundation survey also found that among Americans who could name an objective news source, FOX News was the top-cited outlet. Owned by FOX Corporation, FNC is available in nearly 90 million homes and dominates the cable news landscape, routinely notching the top ten programs in the genre.

transcript:
So DHS assistant secretary Trisha
Mclofflin back with us and good morning
to you. Thank you for your time. We want
to go through a number of things. So
give us a chance to get in there. Okay.
First on this incident inside the church
in St. Paul. They were looking for
someone by the name of David Easterwood
who was listed as a pastor there. In the
videos that we see that's not David
Easterwood, is it? And if not, what
comes after that next?
>> No, that was the lead pastor you saw
there, Bill. But this is outright
hysteria we are seeing from the left.
And this should be the easiest thing in
the world for Tim Walls and Mayor Fry to
condemn. This shouldn't be a Republican
or Democrat issue. These are worshippers
who are practicing their First Amendment
rights to worship. And yet those rights
were trampled on by these protesters who
trespassed and began intimidating these
Christians uh worshiping. So, I'm glad
to see the Department of Justice is
taking this incredibly seriously, and I
hope we see mug shots soon.
>> Uh, Mayor Fry talked about protesters
overall. He was on CNN on Sunday. Watch.
>> Invaded, under siege, occupied,
you know, use whatever word or
superlative that you want to attach, but
the bottom line is what is taking place
is designed to intimidate. It is not
fair. It's not just, and it's completely
unconstitutional. They're peacefully
protesting. They're standing up for one
another. Uh, and you know, like I said,
it's not just going to be resistance
here in this city. We're not backing
down. Um, we're not going to be
intimidated.
>> In addition to that, there's an
investigation now into Mayor Fry. Can
you tell us more?
>> I'm going to leave that to the
Department of Justice, but so much of
what Mayor Fry said there is abjectly
completely false. Oh, I mean, let's
compare what we see in uh places like
Florida or Tennessee where we have state
and local governments work with us. Out
of Florida, we've had 40,000 arrests. We
see public safety. We see peace. We see
calm. Just to pose that to what we see
out of Minnesota where we've had a
little over 10,000 arrests. And we see
riots. We see our law enforcement
officers are being pummeled with rocks
over the weekend. There were fireworks
that were launched at them. They're
being spit on. rampant assaults against
them and so this is not peaceful protest
that we have been seeing. Uh Mayor Fry
should be condemning this. Tim Wallace,
they have to get their city and their
state under control.
>> So Tom Holman has been um outspoken and
I know what you're about to hear is not
going to surprise you, but it sets us up
for a particular question after this.
Watch here.
>> Rhetoric from the mayor and the governor
emboldens that small percentage who go
beyond protesting to criminal activity.
They feel empowered to interfere, impede
with ICE officers, put their hands on
ICE officers, throw weapon, you know,
throw stones and frozen water bottles at
ICE officers. So he was talking about
the rhetoric there. Big picture, Trisha,
I know all of this is important and all
these videos tell a a certain story. Did
you specifically ask the lawmakers in
Minnesota cooperate with you when
[music] it comes to access with the
jails? And if so, when did that happen?
What did they say? And were you ever
granted access to the jails who you
believe hold criminal illegal immigrants
today?
>> Time and time again. I mean, we're
talking about throughout the year, Bill,
that our ICE officers have lodged
detainers. Those detainers have not been
honored. There is a very easy solution
to that, and it's allow our federal law
enforcement, our ICE and CBP officers to
work with the state and local uh
officers on the ground. That's what the
state and local law enforcement officers
want to be doing is enforcing the rule
of law. But if you look at who is in
those jails, currently sitting in those
jails, Bill, 1,370
criminal illegal aliens in Minneapolis's
custody, murderers, rapists, child
pedophiles. Those people should serve
their time and then they should be
turned over to ICE. We have not seen
that. We've seen no cooperation. We have
not been allowed or have those detainers
be honored. That is exactly what we're
asking for today. Mayor Walls and uh
excuse me, Governor Walls and Mayor Fry
should come out today and agree to that.
They should also agree to allowing their
local law enforcement officers to give
our law enforcement officers backup.
That way, when our officers are being
impeded, they're being obstructed, or
they're being assaulted, we don't see
public safety threats and crises like
we've seen the last few days. Um, on a
bigger picture standpoint, ICE is uh
very controversial and it kind of has
been actually not really from the
beginning uh right after 9/11, but
increasingly so. Here's Ruben Ggo. He
thinks it should be scrapped.
>> I think ICE needs to be totally torn
down. Uh, it has to be, you know,
created in the image of what people
want, right? And what does that look
like? From my experience running in
Arizona in a very hard hard state when
it comes to immigration, immigration
issues, people want immigration
enforcement that goes after criminals,
right, and focuses on criminals and
immigration enforcement is actually
focused on security and not the goon
squad that has come from Stephen Miller
and Donald Trump.
>> So with language like that, it doesn't
sound like anyone really wants to be uh
civil and try to solve the problem. And
I think one of the big issues here,
Trisha, is that it doesn't seem that
somebody like Ruben Ggo and President
Trump that they can even agree on what
the problem is that they're trying to
solve. Give you the final word.
>> Well, how deeply on serious during a
serious moment for our country, the
facts on the ground, uh, Dana, is that
70% of those who have been arrested
under the Trump administration, 70,
either have prior criminal convictions
or pending criminal charges against
them. That does not even include known
or suspected terrorists, of which we've
arrested over a thousand. That doesn't
include gang membership. That doesn't
even include being wanted for a violent
crime in your country of origin or a
third country. So, he simply doesn't
have the facts on the ground. What he
should be doing is thanking our ICE and
CBP law enforcement for the great work
that they've done. They wake up every
single day, risk their lives to arrest
child pedophiles, rapists, murderers,
known and suspected terrorists, criminal
gangs that terrorize our communities and
his constituents.
>> 1,370.
I have not heard that number until
today. Uh we will How many other states
are not cooperating, by the way, right
now? Currently,
>> well, it's not just uh states
themselves. There's also jurisdictions
within the state. So when you boil it
down, it can get to cities and other
jurisdictions. So I'd have to come back
to you on that exact number. But you
know, there there's a very easy solution
here. Self-epport now. There doesn't
have to be these arrests. If people
leave now, take the thousand exit bonus,
free flight home, and potentially
preserve the opportunity to return the
right way. Great option for those in
this country illegally.
>> Trish McLolin, thanks for coming back
today. Uh we will follow it as we always
do. Thank you so much. Thank you.
>> Hey, it's Will Kaine. Click here to
subscribe to the Fox News Channel on
YouTube. It's the best way to get our
latest interviews and highlights. and
click to subscribe to the Will Kane
podcast for full episodes right

The number one network in cable, FNC has been the most-watched television news channel for 18 consecutive years. A 2017 Gallup/Knight Foundation survey also found that among Americans who could name an objective news source, FOX News was the top-cited outlet. >> Well, it's all very extreme. And you
think about, you know, they're attacking
law and order and saying that ICE is
extreme. There's nothing extreme about
law and order. What you're seeing is the
extremities in lawlessness, lawlessness
in the streets of Minnesota. And I blame
Governor Walls. He is the top leader in
the state of Minnesota, uh, leading the
state into chaos. And I hope that
President Trump will use whatever means
necessary to bring calm, um, to bring
law and order to the state of Minnesota
and protect the people that live there.
>> The mayor of Minneapolis, Jacob Fry,
says that uh, this is, pardon me, this
is this is sort of about love. I'll let
him say it. Listen to this.
This is not just about resistance here
in Minneapolis. It's about love. We are
showing something far more powerful and
consequential here, which is love. We
are standing up for one another. You've
got neighbors helping neighbors. You've
got people uniting and coming together
in this beautiful way. And obviously
we've got these threats out there from
the federal government that were
literally designed to intimidate
Minneapolis residents to intimidate me.
>> Uh he's talking about neighbors helping
neighbors, but I want to put up a
screenshot of some of the people that
ICE has arrested so far in Minneapolis.
Um people convicted of armed robbery. Um
criminal convictions there. 12 criminal
convictions on Ming Kongyang, Joshua
Forno, who uh was convicted of
thirdderee criminal sexual assault, and
the list goes on. Those are some of the
people that ICE has arrested, but you
wouldn't know that from hearing the
mayor talk. Your thoughts?
>> Well, I didn't under I didn't know that
love meant hugging on rapists,
murderers, and pedophiles. If that's his
definition of love, I don't want any
part of it. And I didn't know that love
meant throwing bottles at federal
agents. It's wild the way that the left
is trying to describe this narrative,
rewrite history when we all can see it
in black and white on TV. The violence
that is unfolding, the defense and the
excuses for hitting an ICE agent with a
vehicle. It's really outrageous and I
just it's perplexing that this is even
happening in the United States of
America.
If none of this were happening, uh I
suppose the the top headline in
Minnesota would be the 9 billion plus in
fraud committed by uh a number of Somali
immigrants and others. Uh fleecing the
state and federal government out of all
kinds of money. Tim Waltz typically
would be held accountable for that, but
he doesn't have to worry about that
right now because of all these protests
going on or at least um it's burying
that story in the uh in the in the
papers.
>> Well, I don't think think anything
anything's going to stop Secretary Scott
Bessent. He has stated that the Treasury
is going to go after the fraud in
Minnesota, and I believe in Secretary
Bessant being able to do that. And I
hope that he investigates Tim Walls and
Keith Ellison to the fullest extent of
the law. And if that means a cold, dark
cell to pay for potential crimes and
cover up that may have been committed,
then so be it. We need to come back to
an era of law and order in this country
where people who break the law are held
accountable. I am tired of judges and
magistrates and prosecutors not
prosecuting, not throwing people in
jail. I don't care the crime. We need we
need to bring lawlessness. We need to
take it off the streets and bring law
and order back to America. That
>> that may be. But Quinnipiac took a poll
and asked Americans how they feel about
the way ICE is handling the immigration
laws in this country and 40% say they
approve while 57% say they disapprove.
What do you attribute those numbers to,
Congresswoman?
>> Certainly, I attribute a much of that to
the lies that are being told in the
mainstream media. The truth that's being
hidden from the American people. I can
tell you running for governor here in
South Carolina, that's not the way
people feel. We respect ICE. We support
ICE and we absolutely uh support the
deportation of criminal illegal aliens
here in South Carolina.
>> Your committee in Congress is going to
be holding a a roundt this week
bipartisan. That's kind of a rare thing
in Washington these days on internet
crimes against children. What are you
hoping to accomplish?
What I'm hoping to accomplish is showing
the American people that partisanship
stops at the door when we're talking
about protecting children. We've seen a
number of uh pieces of legislation that
have come to the floor that have been
drafted that I filed or others have
filed to protect children. And in the
advent of AI, uh, deep fakes, the kind
of the way that technology is advancing
so quickly, the way that social media
and algorithms influence our children
and even predators, we want to make sure
that we are working together handinand,
Republican and Democrat alike, to pro
protect America's children. In fact,
just last week on Thursday, I had a
press conference with more than a dozen
moms who were angered about the release
of a pedophile onto the streets of South
Carolina uh hours after being arrested
for violating his bond. And wouldn't you
know, the local mainstream media had a
media blackout and refused to cover the
story even though they were there to
cover the story. And so, I'm going to be
working overtime with people on both
sides of the aisle that want to expose
this kind of behavior in South Carolina
and beyond. We're going to do it
together.
>> Yeah, it's unfortunate that a lot of the
media have taken sides in political
issues these days. Congresswoman Nancy
Mace of South Carolina. Thanks.
Click here to subscribe to the Fox News
YouTube page to catch our hottest
interviews and most compelling analysis.
You won't get it anywhere else.

transcript:
>> Another wild scene out of Minnesota. New
video appears to show anti-ICE
protesters throwing fireworks at federal
agents in Minneapolis last night.
Demonstrations in the Twin Cities are
intensifying with officials reporting
dozens of arrests since Friday. The
cities and state filed a lawsuit against
the Trump administration yesterday,
calling the recent surge of immigration
agents a federal invasion shortly after
Chicago and Illinois announced they
filed a similar suit. Um Paul Mororrow,
let's get your legal take on the
lawsuits first.
>> Okay. It seems to be grounded first of
all in some federal overreach, but also
the First Amendment. And they're going
to send I'm sure they're going to throw
in some equal protection stuff because
every time it comes up any of the
so-called leaders in these places
invokes racism. Okay, which is amazing
when you consider that all the
protesters tend to be not only white but
majority white women. All right, but
that said, the uh that's the basis of
the lawsuit. The rejoinder is pretty
obvious, which is you do your best
business on Main Street. ICE is going to
these places because that's where the
people they got to pick up are. And all
I would add to bring it down to street
level is the following. As ICE goes into
these locations, one of the things
they've learned, and I've heard them
articulate that, and let's recognize, by
the way, that they're they're hiring, I
think, 5 to 10,000 new ICE agents under
the big beautiful bill. So they're going
to have the bodies to do this. In the
past, if you sent in 100 people to do
the operation, now they're going to send
150, 200. Why? Because they're going to
have arrest teams. So, as they try to
enforce and bring the people out, the
worst of the worst, as we've seen some
of the people that have been arrested in
Minneapolis who are wanted for sex
crimes, uh, you know, child predation,
etc. They're going to have dedicated
arrest teams behind the front lines who
are going to look at this, say, "Okay,
that's the guy. He's shooting fireworks
now at federal officers. That's an
incendiary. That's 5 years in jail with
a sentencing enhancement federally
because obviously Minneapolis PD is all
on furlow. So you go in, you take these
guys, you need the bodies to do this
because it's chaos. And if you don't
have dedicated teams, you lose track of
who did what, the cases fall apart. NYPD
learned this a long time ago. You need
people who are dedicated. I grabbed this
guy. I stay with this guy. I put him
through the system. The arrest sticks.
Now you went out there to play you to
cosplay as a protester when you were on
study hall. Now you're looking at five
years in federal jail. You've got in a
prison. You got to pay for the lawyers.
You have that on your record. That's a
bigger hit and that's way this stops.
>> Harris, we saw last year during the LA
protests that those individuals, the
cosplayers throwing Molotov cocktails at
law enforcement were slapped with tenure
federal charges for the destructive
device that they're throwing. So Paul's
absolutely right. What we are seeing on
unfold before our eyes is is
>> not okay and it is frightening for the
safety of the officers. First of all,
cosplay is so perfect. And I'm glad you
said it again [laughter]
because that's what's going on. I mean,
look, it it would seem that there is no
mission here, just like what we saw on
the university campuses. Who's speaking
up for the people in Iran? Who's even
talking about the Palestinians anymore?
>> Yeah. I mean, all of that went away. So,
it is cosplay. And they're out there
right now becoming, you know, people who
are obstructing justice among the crowd.
They'll pay for that, however, legally,
mightily, if they even get more than a
slap on the hand in the state of
Minnesota because I'm getting the
feeling that Governor Walls, for as long
as he sits in that seat, and some
reports are it won't be much longer. And
then you've got Illinois Governor JB
Pritsker, they want to be the flying
ointment to kind of slow the government
down. They can't stop the feds, but the
feds go in, they do a two-tier job of,
you know, isolating and extracting the
worst of the worst. And then you've got
that second flow, which you just
described. I hadn't heard that. the
arrest teams that will come in and begin
to build cases. So, you can slow down
the process, but you can't stop it. So,
yeah, they're just playing a role right
now. And they're being toolled to death.
I mean, they're just paid.
They're incentivized online. More
clicks, more love from the algorithms. I
mean, think about it, people. This goes
on your professional and your your
personal resume for the rest of your
life.
>> So, Martha Paul, as we talked about the
lawsuits that they have now filed
against the federal government, he
mentioned the First Amendment. So
Minneapolis and Minnesota are arguing
that these are targeted operations
against them. They say that the federal
government that President Trump is
targeting them for their rhetoric that
because they've stood up for motans and
and you know for some reason I guess
calling ICE Gustapo is protected but
they feel that these operations are
unlawful. So they're asking for an
injunction saying to stop it right now.
stop this full ICE operation. And then
number two, rule it completely
unconstitutional because as they say, we
don't need it any more than any other
city. And yet, look, the feds are here
in our backyard. Now, I'm not quite sure
uh what the families of the victims of
those horrific criminals that Paul
mentioned, the the sodomizers and the
rapists and the homicidal maniacs that
were extracted out of Minneapolis. I'm
not sure what they would say to that
argument by Walls and Fry. Well, you
would have to compare whether there's
equal treatment in other cities where
you're not hearing those sorts of things
and how those operations are going when
they have cooperation from local law
enforcement. It's a very different
picture. So, you would have to prove
that they're being treated differently
than those places where the model is
working a bit better. And it does remind
me back to the George Floyd days when
police activity was so suppressed in
Minneapolis where the police officers
abandoned the third precinct in the
middle of the night and drove away. The
people who were hurt the most and we
went out there um and talked to people
on the ground there and in neighborhoods
where they were saying we need police.
We need the police and they are not the
uh characterization of the people that
you said are protesting. These are
people who felt that their streets were
unsafe. They had drive-by shootings.
They had more gang activity in some of
these neighborhoods because the police
were hanging back and and and that is
what makes it a very unsafe situation.
So, and I'm also struck by, you know,
you see protesters out on the streets in
New York, the signs change like every
three weeks, right? So now it's this
poor woman who lost her life. Uh Renee
Good. And you're so right. Where where
are the Palestinian signs? I guess
they're in the storage closet.
>> Well, they turned them over and wrote on
the other side.
>> Even if they did that much
independently, I would be impressed.
Here's your new sign, right?
>> Yeah. It's it's printing the America out
of Iran ones right now.
>> Right. And I I look at it as uh or a
federal agent that maintained his life.
Thank God. Uh in the face of what could
have been imminent drift.
>> Yeah. and to these lawsuits you there's
no first amendment right for states to
opt out of federal immigration
enforcement. That's not how it works.
And you know unfortunately this seems to
be a case that the Supreme Court is
going to have to take up eventually
because right now you have two competing
claims of sovereignty. You have the
sanctuary states that are claiming they
are somehow exempt from the rules of
federal immigration enforcement. And
then you have the federal government
which is trying to apply the rules that
Congress has passed uniformly across all
red and blue states. This is
unsustainable. You can't have blue
states continue to do this. And more to
the point, you can't have the left
believe that they can nullify the
results of an election, a presidential
election in which the mandate of the
people was clear. They voted for
stricter immigration enforcement. And
right now, the left thinks that they can
nullify that through continued violence
against ICE and against Border Patrol
and the other agencies that are
specifically designed for preserving
American sovereignty and identity.
That's a huge problem and it's going to
be more than just a legal question. It's
really a cultural one as well.
>> Hey everyone, I'm Emily Compano. Catch
me and my co-hosts Harris Falner and
Kaylee McNenni on Outnumbered every
weekday at 12 PM Eastern or set your
DVR. Also, don't forget to subscribe to
the Fox News YouTube page for daily
highlights.

co-host of The View, Whoopi Goldberg,
having a walk back comments where she
suggested that ICE agents are criminals.
Watch.
>> This is the thing. You said you were
going after the bad guys.
>> That's what you said, the violent
criminals. And what does it turn out?
The violent criminals seem to be in the
in the agency before folks gather around
and say, "Oh, she's accusing all of the
folks at ICE of being criminals." That
is not what I'm doing.
>> Joining us now is senior writer for the
Washington Examiner and Fox News
contributor Joe Kcha. And uh Joe, that
little transition that we played during
the clip, that was before and then after
the commercial break. So, what do you
think of about Whoopi Goldberg's two
opposing comments there?
Uh, Carly Todd, I think Whoopi only
walked back those statements uh because
she was told to do so by ABC's legal
team. And when she walks back these
statements, I I I mean, it's basically
the broadcast version of a hostage
video. You could tell she did not want
to do it, but she had to do it because
ABC's been sued before uh by President
Trump, by the Trump administration, and
they've had to settle to the tune of
millions of dollars. Uh but then again,
if it let's put it this way, the the
main point is that crazy town has only
been expanded in terms of rhetoric from
the from the left. I mean, ICE is
putting away, as we know, and deporting
violent criminals. We're talking about
sex offenders. We're talking about child
traffickers. We're talking about
murderers and rapists. And and every
mayor in every major city where they're
carrying out their operations should be
thankful for making them look better and
making their city safer for everyone.
And again, if you hit any law
enforcement officer with a car or an
SUV, those are considered deadly
weapons. There will be consequences. And
in this case, the ICE officer who was
hit, he had been rammed by a vehicle not
too long ago that required him to get 33
stitches. Overall, ramming or attempted
rammings of ICE officers is up 3,200%
when compared to 2024. But that's a stat
you're simply not reading or hearing
very much in terms of the coverage we're
seeing out of Minneapolis uh by by much
of the media outside of this network.
Tom,
>> feel like the view was due for an
inflammatory headline making comment.
And here we go. They kick off the new
year just the way they always ended the
last one. Uh before we let you go, a new
Gallup poll finding that 45% of
Americans now identify as independent,
rejecting the country's two major
parties, which both sit at 27%. 30
seconds to you. How should Republicans
take that knowledge, take that data and
use it to their advantage in the
midterms?
>> Uh, it is amazing, Todd. I mean, Gallup
has never found this many Americans
claiming uh the independent uh label.
Overall, I'll leave it here. It's likely
more voters are identifying as
independents out of disdain and
frustration for toxic partisan politics
from both sides. They simply don't want
to be associated with this stuff. But
overall, I think that's an opening for
Republicans. Uh because I think in the
end the common sense stuff, tax cuts, a
closed border, all the things that
President Trump has been doing on a
foreign policy perspective and low gas
prices that favors Republicans and not
Democrats, even if they identify as
independents. Todd Carly,
>> I know. And that's why uh President
Trump calling Elizabeth Warren I think
is so important because while people
think that they like the hyperbolic
rhetoric, usually unity is what most
Americans really want to see. Got to
leave it there. Fox and Friends starts
right now.
>> I'm Steve Ducey. I'm Brian Kilme
>> and I'm Anley Airheart. And click here
to subscribe to the Fox News YouTube
page to catch our hottest interviews and
most compelling analysis.

transcript:
Well, let's talk a little bit more about
it because we're staying in Minneapolis
where three Venezuelan migrants who
allegedly attacked and ambushed an ICE
agent this week are in custody for what
the Trump administration is now calling
attempted murder.
This ICE agent was executing a targeted
operation against a Venezuelan illegal
alien who was unlawfully present in the
country. They used a shovel or broom to
smash his face in. And so, yes, that
agent had to use self-defense and take
up his weapon to protect his own life.
That is what's happening on the streets
of Minneapolis. That's what's happening
on the streets, unfortunately, of these
Democrat-run cities and states where you
have elected officials who are
encouraging such such violence against
our brave men and women in law
enforcement.
>> Former DHS Deputy Assistant Secretary
Jonathan Fehee joins us now. And
Jonathan, as you well know, the
president came out yesterday and said,
"Look, if this keeps up, I'm going to
have to use the Insurrection Act." And
for those people who don't know, the
Insurrection Act uh is called for when
quoteun unlawful obstructions make it
impracticable to enforce federal law.
Jonathan, is it time?
Yeah, the the certainly it the situation
fits the law perfectly because you have
consistent obstruction of the law
encouraged by these elected officials.
So, they have no no interest in even
toning things down. I think it's
appropriate, you know, and and President
Trump has let this go on long enough
and, you know, you look back to 2020,
their city burned down because Waltz and
the mayor didn't take appropriate action
and I don't think it's a President
Trump's going to allow that to happen
again. So, I think it probably is going
to happen. I think it's entirely
appropriate and it's entirely legally
justified. We learned this week,
Jonathan, that the ICE agent who shot um
uh Rachel Good uh was suffered some
internal bleeding to the torso. It's a
fact that I'm sure many people who don't
like ICE will not believe no matter who
says it. But he also reportedly served
in the military for years and is a
wellrespected member of immigration and
custom enforcement and has an immigrant
wife himself. Uh so what do you think
his future looks like?
I think it's very scary for him because
if you look back to some of these other
previous incidents, if you look back to
the hands up, don't shoot. Remember
Darren Wilson had to go into hiding. I
don't know what ever happened to him,
but he got so many threats even though
it was found by a Democrat investigation
that he was entirely justified. So, I
think this agent is, you know, he's
going to have a target on his back, his
family will. It's very scary for him
because no agent wants to ever have to
use their firearm, but he he did what he
was required to do and what he was
trained to do. And it's so shameful the
way that, you know, people are talking
about him as if he he murdered this
woman or did anything else. But yeah, he
was in danger. He was injured and he did
what he was supposed to do. And you
know, just like the the incident the
that you were just talking about at the
beginning with the other agent that was
being beaten by people he was trying to
arrest. They have a very dangerous job.
They deserve the support. But yeah, I do
fear for his safety and his future.
>> And I said Rachel apologies. Her name is
of course Renee Good.
>> Understood. And Jonathan, you know,
somebody who's very very concerned for
the health and safety of these border
agents is their boss. Borders are Tom
Holman. He gave this urgent warning.
Listen.
If the hateful rehe doesn't stop,
there's going to be more bloodshed. It's
not over. And what what scares you the
most, there's going to be another death
either of an agent or or or
somebody that's, you know, steps over
that line. I buried border patrol agents
throughout my career. I buried uh
special agents. The worst thing I've
ever done in my career is handed a
folder flag to a spouse or a child. I
pray every night that I never have to do
that again. And obviously we're
referring to border agents and ICE
agents sort of interchangeably here even
though they are two distinct bodies. Uh
Tim Walls asked Donald Trump to tone
down the rhetoric. He asked Donald Trump
to tone down the rhetoric uh literally
minutes after he himself inflamed said
rhetoric. What do you make of that
double standard, that hypocrisy
demonstrated by the current governor of
Minnesota?
>> I would say it's sort of it's
breathtaking, but it's consistent for
the course. and yet talking out of both
sides of his mouth. There's been nobody
that has done more to inflame tensions
than Tim Waltz. I mean, he was just
after that saying, "Record the ICE agent
and the atrocities they're committing."
He's called them Nazis. He's done
everything he can to stir things up. And
it's so awful because, you know, a lot
of us, you know, he's sort of a people
make fun of him a lot, but there are
people that take him seriously. So when
he is up there saying things, people
take him seriously and then want to act
out and try to harm ICE agents and harm
law enforcement. And yeah, it's totally
shameful. His job is to be an adult and
he can't live up to that job because he
should get up there and say these agents
have the legitimate right to be here.
They are enforcing the law and if you
want to protest, protest, but don't get
in their way. But instead, he wants
tension. He wants conflict. He wants
violence. And it's so shameful and he's
going to be the primary reason if
President Trump invokes the insurrection
act because Tim Waltz won't simply do
his job and keep his community safe.
>> Uh both sides are accusing the other of
uh escalating tensions and causing chaos
and both sides are right that tensions
are certainly escalating with no signs
of cooling down anytime soon. Former DHS
Deputy Assistant Secretary Jonathan
Fehee, we appreciate you joining us as
always.
>> I'm Steve Ducey. I'm Brian Kilme.
>> And I'm Anley Airheart. And click here

page to catch our hottest interviews and
most compelling analysis.

transcript:
Uh we are learning some new details
about ICE watch. That is a network
across the country that claims to be
legal observers of ICE operations. But
here's what DHS sources tell us. ICE
aims to monitor, track, interfere, and
oppose ongoing federal immigration
enforcement operations. The group is
present in multiple sanctuary cities
across the country. It is linked to
multiple confrontations with federal
agents throughout the country and
allegedly involved in numerous instances
of activists ramming agents with their
cars. Renee Nicole Good was allegedly
part of that group, which has no formal
leadership. Federal authorities are now
looking into those networks to determine
who is funding them and who's training
them. Joining me now to talk about this
is Jeffrey Holstead, Genesis Spokman and
a former Fort Worth, Texas Chief of
Police. Thank you so much uh for being
with us this morning. Greatly appreciate
it. Uh
>> good morning.
>> Good [clears throat] morning to you.
This is a really tough topic for people
across the nation that that are looking
at the videos and and coming out of this
with very different perspectives and
politicians coming out with very
different perspectives. But when it
comes to these organizations like ICE
which exist in many different forms
across the country, ICEWatch itself
across the country but other similar
organizations as well that operate in
similar ways but under different names.
Uh your thoughts on the challenges that
pose they pose particularly when it
comes to aggressive tactics like
including vehicles in their activities.
>> Well, I've had a lot of experience
trying to work with these groups. If you
remember in the early 1990s, community-
based policing was all across America
and it was very successful, very
productive and as a field force
commander. I would actually meet with
protest groups, cop watch and other
affiliated groups and work on their
legal capacity to work with us, march,
protest, and do it peacefully. I think
that's gone away with this political
divisiveness we see around the US. And
now these groups don't want to work with
law enforcement, communicate,
collaborate, share information or learn.
As chief, it was very, very important
that I would get activists into the
academy and show them how we train on
use of force. They became better
informed activists and they really
became partners with us so that they
could protest peacefully. We could do
our job safely and we had relationships
that worked. Those relationships aren't
existing in Minnesota and that is
horrible. Can you imagine any sort of
scenario where ICE Watch would be
willing to cooperate, communicate with
ICE? It seems that their uh effort is to
shut the organization down, to shut the
agency down.
>> If they truly wanted to have an impact
and make positive, proactive change,
they would build communicationbased
relationships. I know this because we
built a platform that allows law
enforcement to collaborate and share
sensitive information in encrypted
portal legally with these protest groups
and those agencies that do that don't
have these issues. So ICE watch could
work effectively with ICE. We have a
very steep hill to climb to start making
this relationship work, but there's
avenues for them to do this successfully
and start making proactive change that
keeps their members safe. You know, one
more question. There are a lot of people
that might want to be part of an
organization like Ice Watch, but they're
part of a different organization, an
organization that perhaps has a
different name for what they call the
people that are tracking ICE out on the
streets. And Ice Watch was using terms
like legal observer. I've heard
verifiers used before. Some
organizations say, you know, we go, we
take pictures, we stand back at least
seven feet. We let the agents know that
we're there. And but what about the
training of people that are really going
into dangerous situations uh where you
don't know who's being arrested, you
don't know where the situation will go
and you're standing 7 feet away, 10 feet
away shouting things at officers. Your
thoughts on any sort of training that
might be happening with these
organizations.
>> You know, you bring up an excellent
point. And I've talked about this for
over a decade now because anytime
there's a high-profile use of force
incident or a deadly force encounter,
the immediate reaction is we want all of
the training from that law enforcement
entity. But when there is fault, alleged
misconduct, or potential violations of
law of a protest or activism group,
where's their records of training? Where
is their professional accountability?
Where is their litigation that could be
filed against them because you didn't
train your members accordingly? they can
work with their local police departments
and learn about how we train and prepare
and become partners in this effort. We
want them to have peaceful protests. We
want to work with them. We just want
them to work with us so we can help them
train and learn more effectively on how
we mobilize and how we handle these
potentially violent incidents. And then
it's become a much safer incident and
there's teamwork involved
>> and that sounds like something that
could potentially save lives. Uh, we
